title: The Sawmill Accident
description: A worker was injured at the Småstad sawmill. The third accident this year.
lead_text: Karl at the sawmill hurt himself yesterday...
preview: Anonymous note slipped under the door. Hastily written.

interview.opening_line: Yeah? What do you want? My hand hurts and I'd rather be left alone.

q1_options.text: That must have been terrible. How are you really doing, Karl?
Karl, this is the third accident this year. What's going on at the sawmill?
People say the owner knew about the deficiencies. Is that true?

friendly.q1_response: Well... it hurts. But it's not the first time someone's been injured in there. The machine has been acting up for a while. We've reported it but...
friendly.expression_hint: Relaxes a little, looks down at the bandage

q2_options.text: Have you reported it to the labor safety board?
Tell me about the machine. What exactly is broken?
You mentioned others have been hurt. Who?

outcomes.response: We called once. Then Bengtsson said he'd fix it. But nothing happened.
outcomes.feedback: Basic — you got confirmation but no explosive details.
outcomes.note: Then Bengtsson said he'd fix it

outcomes.response: It's the safety guard. It came loose in the spring. Bengtsson said a new one costs too much — he's planning to sell. Nobody's supposed to know the place is falling apart. All repairs were stopped in March.
outcomes.feedback: Full story — sale + deliberate negligence. Strong.
outcomes.note: Bengtsson said a new one costs too much

outcomes.response: Erik broke his arm in June. Sven got stitches in August. All the same machine. The union knows but Bengtsson threatens to shut down if they say anything.
outcomes.feedback: Good — you got the pattern, but missed the financial connection.
outcomes.note: The union knows but Bengtsson threatens to shut down...

friendly.q1_note: We've reported it but

direct.q1_response: Three accidents, yeah. Everyone knows. But nobody writes about it. Bengtsson owns half the town, doesn't he.
direct.expression_hint: Arms crossed, sizing you up

q2_options.text: What do you mean by 'he owns half the town'?
Do you have documentation of the accidents? Reports?
Are you afraid Bengtsson will shut down the sawmill as revenge?

outcomes.response: Bengtsson sits on the municipal council. His brother is the building inspector. Who are you supposed to complain to? They protect each other.
outcomes.feedback: Corruption link — strong, but you missed the sale plan.
outcomes.note: His brother is the building inspector

outcomes.response: Reports? Who writes reports? Sven-Erik took notes in the union logbook but it disappeared from the office.
outcomes.feedback: You got a hint of a cover-up but no chain of evidence.
outcomes.note: Sven-Erik took notes in the union logbook but it...

outcomes.response: Afraid? I've got three kids. Of course I'm afraid. But you know what — word is he's going to sell to some Gothenburg company anyway. We're out regardless.
outcomes.feedback: The sale hint came through — but not the details.
outcomes.note: Word is he's going to sell to some Gothenburg company...

direct.q1_note: Bengtsson owns half the town, doesn't he

pressure.q1_response: Wh— wait a minute. Who have you been talking to? I didn't say I wanted to be interviewed.

q2_options.text: I have sources saying Bengtsson deliberately ignored safety. Comment?
If you don't talk, I'll publish anyway — but then without your side of the story.
I understand you're worried. But think about your colleagues. The next accident could be worse.

outcomes.response: I can't comment on that. Go talk to the union instead.
outcomes.feedback: He shut down. It became a thin story.
outcomes.note: Go talk to the union instead

outcomes.response: Are you threatening me? We're done here. Leave.
outcomes.feedback: Interview terminated. You got no information at all.
outcomes.note: Are you threatening me. We're done here

outcomes.response: *Silence* ...You're right. Sven-Erik is at home with an arm he can barely move. Last week Bengtsson said 'shut up or clock out'. His exact words.
outcomes.feedback: You got a direct quote through empathy after pressure — effective.
outcomes.note: Last week Bengtsson said 'shut up or clock out'

pressure.q1_note: I didn't say I wanted to be interviewed

silence.q1_response: ...Are you just going to stand there? Okay. *sighs* What do you actually want to know?
silence.expression_hint: Uncomfortable, waiting

q2_options.text: Tell me how the accident happened. In your own words.
What do you think happens if nobody speaks up?
I have time. Take as long as you need.

outcomes.response: I was feeding the planks and the guard was gone. Has been gone since April. We taped up a warning but Bengtsson tore it down. 'Takes too long to run with the guard on' he said.
outcomes.feedback: Strong testimony — he spoke freely without pressure.
outcomes.note: We taped up a warning but Bengtsson tore it down

outcomes.response: Someone else dies. That's what happens. But Bengtsson doesn't care. He's moving on anyway.
outcomes.feedback: Emotional truth but no details.
outcomes.note: Bengtsson doesn't care

outcomes.response: *long pause* Bengtsson removed all the safety equipment in March. We found emails — his secretary showed me — where he writes to the buyers that 'the equipment is in top condition'. All lies. Three injuries and he sells the place as if nothing happened. The insurance company doesn't know either.
outcomes.feedback: Jackpot — documented evidence trail, insurance fraud, all through patience.
outcomes.note: Bengtsson removed all the safety equipment in March

silence.q1_note: What do you actually want to know

title: The Missing Girl
description: 14-year-old Anna Ekberg hasn't come home from school since Thursday.
lead_text: My daughter never came home yesterday
preview: Desperate parent calls the newsroom early in the morning.

interview.opening_line: Thank you for coming. The police say she's probably just 'hanging out with friends'. But Anna doesn't do that. She always comes home.

q1_options.text: I understand your worry, Birgitta. Tell me about Anna — what kind of person is she?
When and where was Anna last seen? We need a timeline.
The police don't seem to be taking this seriously. Why do you think that is?

friendly.q1_response: Anna is... she's quiet. Responsible. Cleans her room without being asked. She would never just disappear. Something has happened, I know it.
friendly.expression_hint: Eyes tearing up, holding it together

q2_options.text: Has Anna mentioned anything unusual lately? A new person, a conflict?
Which route does she usually take home from school?
Have you talked to her classmates? What do they say?

outcomes.response: Now that you ask... she mentioned a teacher. Mr. Svensson. Said he asked her to stay after school sometimes for 'extra help'. I didn't think about it then but... and yesterday she was supposed to stay after school.
outcomes.feedback: Complete — you got the critical connection by letting her talk freely.
outcomes.note: Yesterday she was supposed to stay after school

outcomes.response: She always walks along Storgatan and then through the park. The police haven't even searched the park properly.
outcomes.feedback: Geographic info — useful but not the core of the story.
outcomes.note: The police haven't even searched the park properly

outcomes.response: Lisa, her best friend, said Anna seemed scared the past week. Didn't want to be alone. And she had stopped eating lunch at school — sat instead in the hallway outside the teachers' room.
outcomes.feedback: Behavioral change + school connection — strong clues.
outcomes.note: Sat instead in the hallway outside the teachers' room

friendly.q1_note: Something has happened, I know it

direct.q1_response: Thursday at three she was supposed to be home. She left school at quarter to three according to the janitor. After that — nothing.
direct.expression_hint: Composed but tense, checking her hands

q2_options.text: Who was the last person to see her at school?
Have the police checked her route to school?
Does Anna have a diary or does she write letters to anyone?

outcomes.response: The janitor, Göte, said she was talking to a teacher at the gate. He couldn't see which one. But Anna seemed... reluctant, Göte said. Like she was hesitating.
outcomes.feedback: Eyewitness at the right moment — you know a teacher was involved.
outcomes.note: Reluctant, Göte said

outcomes.response: They 'checked' on Friday. Two patrol cars for twenty minutes. That's it. Commissioner Lund said that 'teenage girls hide sometimes'.
outcomes.feedback: Police failure — good angle but you missed the school connection.
outcomes.note: Commissioner Lund said that 'teenage girls hide...

outcomes.response: Diary... yes. I found it last night under the mattress. I didn't look inside — it's private — but... *hesitates* She wrote 'S is doing it again' on the cover. In red. I don't know what it means.
outcomes.feedback: Diary with initial + desperation. Explosive. Bold to ask the right question.
outcomes.note: I don't know what it means

direct.q1_note: She left school at quarter to three according to the...

pressure.q1_response: Why? I... I don't know. Maybe because we're not important enough. Anna's father left three years ago. We have no name, no connections.

q2_options.text: Do you think the police are hiding something?
Is there anyone in Anna's circle you suspect?
Birgitta — if I'm going to help you, you need to tell me everything. Even the hard parts.

outcomes.response: Hiding? No... they're just lazy. Commissioner Lund plays golf with the principal. They protect the school, not Anna.
outcomes.feedback: Interesting connection but speculative — hard to publish.
outcomes.note: Commissioner Lund plays golf with the principal

outcomes.response: *long silence* There's a teacher. Svensson. Anna said he was 'creepy'. I told her to talk to the principal. Now I wonder if the principal even listened.
outcomes.feedback: You got the name — but through pressure, not trust. It shows.
outcomes.note: Now I wonder if the principal even listened

outcomes.response: *breaks down* Anna told me last summer. That a teacher was touching her. I went to the principal. He said it was a 'misunderstanding'. I should have gone to the police. And now she's gone. It's my fault.
outcomes.feedback: The full picture — abuse, cover-up by the school, police inaction. Enormous.
outcomes.note: It's my fault

pressure.q1_note: We have no name, no connections

silence.q1_response: *waits, nervously* Aren't you going to ask anything? I... I don't know where to start.
silence.expression_hint: Nervous, needs guidance

q2_options.text: Start with what worries you the most right now.
What do you want people to know about Anna?
What haven't you told the police?

outcomes.response: What worries me... is that the school is lying. The principal called me yesterday and said 'Anna was frequently absent'. That's not true. She doesn't have a single absence. Why are they lying?
outcomes.feedback: The school's lies — strong angle, you let her steer.
outcomes.note: She doesn't have a single absence

outcomes.response: Anna plays the flute. She dreams of Stockholm. She folds paper cranes when she's nervous. She deserves better than being a brief notice in the paper.
outcomes.feedback: Human portrait — good writing but weak news basis.
outcomes.note: She deserves better than being a brief notice in the...

outcomes.response: *starts crying* I didn't tell the police that... Anna said 'he' threatened her. That if she told anyone, 'nobody would believe her anyway, because he's a teacher'. I should have listened. God, I should have listened.
outcomes.feedback: Through silence you got what she didn't dare tell the police. Journalism at its best.
outcomes.note: Anna said 'he' threatened her

silence.q1_note: I don't know where to start

title: The Land Deal
description: The municipality is buying farmland for a new industrial area at a suspiciously low price.
lead_text: The municipality is buying Persson's land cheap. The price is far below market value, and a municipal commissioner has personal ties to the buyer.
preview: Copy of municipal minutes, unofficially shared.

interview.opening_line: What can you say. They offered money and I need it. The farm doesn't pay its way anymore.

q1_options.text: That sounds like a tough situation, Erik. How long has the farm been in the family?
How much did the municipality offer? And what is the land actually worth?
The municipal commissioner and you are old friends. Was it a clean deal?

friendly.q1_response: Since 1890. My grandfather broke the land. It hurts to sell but the kids don't want to take over and the bank wants its money.
friendly.expression_hint: Sad, gazing out the window

q2_options.text: Did you feel you had a choice, or were you pressured?
What is the municipality going to build on the land?
Did you get help from a lawyer to review the offer?

outcomes.response: Choice? The bank called every week. Then the commissioner showed up with an offer. 'Take it or leave it,' he said. I took it.
outcomes.feedback: You got a personal story but no concrete news.
outcomes.note: Then the commissioner showed up with an offer

outcomes.response: They said 'industrial area' but I heard it's mostly planned as parking and storage for the municipality's own vehicles. The land was worth twice as much if they had zoned it for housing.
outcomes.feedback: Zoning manipulation — land undervalued through zone category. Good!
outcomes.note: The land was worth twice as much if they had zoned it...

outcomes.response: Lawyer? I couldn't afford one. The municipality's lawyer handled everything. Which isn't exactly... normal, is it?
outcomes.feedback: Hint of conflicts of interest but no figures.
outcomes.note: The municipality's lawyer handled everything

friendly.q1_note: It hurts to sell but the kids don't want to take over...

direct.q1_response: They gave me 180,000. Neighbor Olsson got 300,000 for a similar plot last year. I'm no expert but that feels... low.
direct.expression_hint: Fingers drumming on the table

q2_options.text: Do you know who approved the price in the municipality?
Can I see the contract?
Why do you think the price was so much lower than Olsson's?

outcomes.response: Commissioner Björk brought it up in the committee. Himself. Without mentioning that we went to school together and that he's leased my pasture land for free for ten years.
outcomes.feedback: Conflict of interest — the commissioner prepared his own case. Publishable.
outcomes.note: Commissioner Björk brought it up in the committee

outcomes.response: The contract? They said it was confidential until the deal was closed. I didn't get a copy.
outcomes.feedback: The secrecy is a story but you need more.
outcomes.note: I didn't get a copy

outcomes.response: Lower? Let me tell you why. Olsson's land was zoned 'residential' — mine was kept as 'agricultural' right up until the sale. But the INTERNAL planning documents say 'mixed use with municipal priority.' An independent assessor valued my land at 1.2 million in 2023. The municipality paid 600,000. And here's the kicker: the farmer who — well, that's me — my daughter works at the planning office. No wait, I mean the COUNCIL'S daughter. Björk's girl. SHE handled the zoning application. She never declared the conflict. The municipal auditor flagged it six months ago but the report was delayed until after the council voted.
outcomes.feedback: Conflict of interest, suppressed audit, undervaluation with proof. The farmer connects the dots when asked directly.
outcomes.note: Björk's daughter handled the zoning — the auditor's report was delayed until after the vote

direct.q1_note: Neighbor Olsson got 300,000 for a similar plot last...

pressure.q1_response: Friends? We play cards sometimes. What do you mean by that?

q2_options.text: Did you get any promise beyond the money? Building permit, lease?
I've heard the commissioner leases your land. For free. Is that true?
Did Björk chew you out in the middle of the deal if you broke these plans?

outcomes.response: Promise? No. Money. That was all. Period.
outcomes.feedback: Blocked — he shut down. The pressure came too early.
outcomes.note: Money. That was all

outcomes.response: *blushes* That... he's been doing that for ten years, yes. But that has nothing to do with the land deal. Or does it?
outcomes.feedback: Conflict of interest confirmed — but by accident rather than trust.
outcomes.note: That has nothing to do with the land deal

outcomes.response: That's enough. Get out of here. I have nothing more to say.
outcomes.feedback: Interview ended. You spooked your source.
outcomes.note: I have nothing more to say

pressure.q1_note: We play cards sometimes. What do you mean by that

silence.q1_response: *fidgets* I know it looks strange. That I sold for too little money to a friend. But I had no choice.
silence.expression_hint: Avoids eye contact

q2_options.text: Why did you have no choice?
What looks strange, you mean?
Who pressured you — the bank or the municipality?

outcomes.response: The bank threatened foreclosure. Björk said 'take my offer or the municipality buys after the auction for even less'. So I signed.
outcomes.feedback: Extortion — the municipality exploited his debt. Strong angle.
outcomes.note: So I signed

outcomes.response: That the price is too low. Everyone knows it. But nobody says anything because Björk decides on building permits and everyone needs Björk.
outcomes.feedback: Power structure — but no figures or evidence.
outcomes.note: Nobody says anything because Björk decides on building...

outcomes.response: Both. The bank came first. Then Björk showed up as the 'savior'. Savior? He saved himself.
outcomes.feedback: Good quote but you need documentation.
outcomes.note: Then Björk showed up as the 'savior'

silence.q1_note: That I sold for too little money to a friend

title: The Dog Show in Småstad
description: A dog show at Folkets Park ended in arguments about a biased judge.
lead_text: You heard there was a commotion at the dog show yesterday. Something about the judge...
preview: An elderly lady called out to you outside Konsum.

interview.opening_line: Finally! Someone who'll listen! What happened yesterday was pure FRAUD!

q1_options.text: Oh, tell me! What happened at the show?
Maj-Britt, who was the judge and what went wrong?
I heard you lost and got angry. Is that the whole story?

friendly.q1_response: Well, we had a dog show at Folkets Park. My Bella — a WONDERFUL dachshund — didn't even get a ribbon. And do you know who won? The judge's sister-in-law!
friendly.expression_hint: Gesticulating wildly, cheeks flushed with indignation

q2_options.text: Are you sure the judge and the winner are related?
How did the other dog owners react?
What did the organizers say afterward?

outcomes.response: Yes indeed! Sister-in-law! Everyone knows it. Ulla-Karin Persson is her name. Married to the judge's brother Stig. It's well known in the whole district.
outcomes.feedback: You got the family connection confirmed. Small but fun story.
outcomes.note: Married to the judge's brother Stig

outcomes.response: Arne Björkqvist was furious — he competed with his German shepherd. Agneta simply went home. At least five people were upset.
outcomes.feedback: Multiple dissatisfied — it strengthens the story a bit.
outcomes.note: He competed with his German shepherd

outcomes.response: The organizers? They're all the same crowd! The Småstad Kennel Club — three people who decide everything.
outcomes.feedback: Vague — she blames everyone but gives no details.
outcomes.note: The Småstad Kennel Club

friendly.q1_note: The judge's sister-in-law

direct.q1_response: The judge was Rolf Danielsson from Eksjö. And his sister-in-law Ulla-Karin won with her poodle. Obvious conflict of interest!
direct.expression_hint: Pointing with her whole hand, holding the leash in the other

q2_options.text: Do you have any proof besides them being related?
How was Rolf Danielsson chosen as judge?
Have you filed a formal complaint?

outcomes.response: Proof? Look at my Bella! She's PERFECT! That should be proof enough.
outcomes.feedback: No substance — just a sore loser.
outcomes.note: That should be proof enough

outcomes.response: Chosen? Ha! Nobody 'chose' him. Ulla-Karin SUGGESTED him — to her own sister on the board. They didn't even ask the kennel club. And this isn't the first time: Rolf judged in Kisa last year, same breed class, same winner. I have the protocols from THREE shows. Bengt was going to report it to the Swedish Kennel Club — but Ulla-Karin's sister got him voted off the board first. The whole selection process is a sham. I can show you the minutes.
outcomes.feedback: Rigged selection process, pattern across multiple shows, whistleblower silenced. Full story.
outcomes.note: Same judge, same winner across THREE shows — Bengt was voted off the board to silence him

outcomes.response: Complaint? To whom? The kennel club has no appeals process. That's why I'm talking to you!
outcomes.feedback: No formal process — the story has no legs.
outcomes.note: That's why I'm talking to you

direct.q1_note: The judge was Rolf Danielsson from Eksjö

pressure.q1_response: WHAT?! Got angry? I didn't get angry — I was OFFENDED! On my Bella's behalf!
pressure.expression_hint: Chin trembling, the dachshund growling softly at her feet

q2_options.text: Sorry, I didn't mean to— Tell me your version.
Are there witnesses who can confirm the cheating?
What do you want to happen now?

outcomes.response: *softens* Well... it was Rolf Danielsson who judged. And his sister-in-law won. It doesn't look good, does it?
outcomes.feedback: You saved the interview — basic facts confirmed.
outcomes.note: It was Rolf Danielsson who judged

outcomes.response: Everyone SAW it! But nobody dares say anything because Gösta on the board decides who gets to participate next year.
outcomes.feedback: Rumors but no named witnesses.
outcomes.note: Nobody dares say anything because Gösta on the board...

outcomes.response: I want Bella to get the ribbon she deserves! And for Rolf to never judge again!
outcomes.feedback: Emotion without facts — no story.
outcomes.note: For Rolf to never judge again

pressure.q1_note: On my Bella's behalf

silence.q1_response: ...Listen, are you going to write something down or what? I'm not standing here for my health!
silence.expression_hint: Tapping foot impatiently, the dachshund yawns

q2_options.text: I'm listening. Tell me from the beginning.
I want to understand the full picture before I write anything.
Who do you think I should talk to besides you?

outcomes.response: *sighs deeply* Okay. Rolf Danielsson judged. His sister-in-law won. Arne Björkqvist and I protested but Gösta on the board dismissed us.
outcomes.feedback: Compact summary — all names in place.
outcomes.note: Arne Björkqvist and I protested but Gösta on the board...

outcomes.response: The full picture? It's SIMPLE! Rigged results, questionable judge, wishy-washy board. Don't laugh!
outcomes.feedback: No new details — mostly frustration.
outcomes.note: Rigged results, questionable judge, wishy-washy board

outcomes.response: Talk to Arne Björkqvist. He always films with his Super 8 camera. He might have filmed the judging!
outcomes.feedback: Good lead — possible documentation.
outcomes.note: He always films with his Super 8 camera

silence.q1_note: I'm not standing here for my health

title: The Church Bells That Never Stop
description: Residents near the church complain that the bells ring in the middle of the night.
lead_text: A neighbor to the church has written in to complain about the bell ringing...
preview: Letter in the newsroom's mailbox. Neat handwriting on blue paper.

interview.opening_line: I haven't slept properly in three months. THREE MONTHS! It rings at half past three in the morning!

q1_options.text: Three months without sleep, that sounds terrible. Tell me what's happening.
Gunnar, have you talked to the vicar about the problem?
Aren't they just regular church bells? People have lived near churches for hundreds of years.

friendly.q1_response: The new bell tower mechanism they installed in May — it's BROKEN. Rings at the wrong times. Half past three, quarter to two, completely random. My wife Ingrid cries at night.
friendly.expression_hint: Dark circles under the eyes, graying temples

q2_options.text: Do other neighbors have the same problem?
Do you know why they replaced the bell mechanism?
Have you documented the times it rings?

outcomes.response: The Svensson family across the road — they have a three-year-old who wakes up every time. And Mrs. Alm by the hill has written to the municipality three times with no reply.
outcomes.feedback: Multiple affected — good basis for a human interest story.
outcomes.note: The Svensson family across the road

outcomes.response: The old mechanism worked fine. But the church board wanted something modern. Ordered from some German company. The cheapest bid of course.
outcomes.feedback: Background on the problem — substandard procurement.
outcomes.note: Ordered from some German company

outcomes.response: Documented? No, I'm lying awake! But it rings whenever it wants, I can swear to that.
outcomes.feedback: No evidence — just experience.
outcomes.note: It rings whenever it wants, I can swear to that

friendly.q1_note: My wife Ingrid cries at night

direct.q1_response: Talked to him? I've YELLED at him! Vicar Falk says 'the repairman is coming next week'. He's been saying that since July.
direct.expression_hint: Pounds the table, the teabag jumps out of the cup

q2_options.text: Is there any written promise of repair?
Have you contacted the municipal environmental board?
What would you say if I talked to Falk directly?

outcomes.response: Written? Falk promises everything verbally. Never a document.
outcomes.feedback: Nothing documented — hard to write about.
outcomes.note: Never a document

outcomes.response: Mrs. Alm called the environmental board. They said churches are exempt from noise disturbance regulations. But this isn't about NORMAL bell ringing!
outcomes.feedback: Legal loophole — interesting angle.
outcomes.note: They said churches are exempt from noise disturbance...

outcomes.response: Talk to Falk? He's slippery as an eel. But go ahead. And ask him why it's taken seven months to fix a clock!
outcomes.feedback: You got the green light and a good question to ask.
outcomes.note: Ask him why it's taken seven months to fix a clock

direct.q1_note: He's been saying that since July

pressure.q1_response: REGULAR church bells?! Half past three in the morning is regular?! Have you ever— No, sorry. I'm just so tired.
pressure.expression_hint: Face reddens, then presses his hand to his forehead

q2_options.text: Sorry, that was clumsy. Tell me about the nights.
I understand you're frustrated. How many people are affected?
Has the nighttime ringing been going on since the new mechanism was installed?

outcomes.response: The nights... *yawns* I hear it chiming and then I can't fall back asleep. Ingrid can't either. We're retirees. We deserve some peace.
outcomes.feedback: Human touch but nothing new.
outcomes.note: We deserve some peace

outcomes.response: There are at least eight households. I know because Ingrid went around with a list. Eight families who all hear it.
outcomes.feedback: Quantification — eight households gives the story weight.
outcomes.note: I know because Ingrid went around with a list

outcomes.response: Since the new mechanism? YES! That's exactly when it started! The vicar's nephew installed it — kid's not even an electrician! He did it for free, and now nobody knows how to fix it. The company that made the system went bankrupt. The diocese KNOWS but won't pay for a real technician because it means admitting the nephew botched it. npc_title: Member of the municipal council (Social Democrats)

interview.opening_line: The parking lot? Right. It was approved on Thursday. What do you want to know?

q1_options.text: Hi Rune! Just some background — how did the proposal come about?
Why is a new parking lot needed right in the middle of the square?
Several council members reportedly voted against it. Was the decision controversial?

friendly.q1_response: It was Björk who brought it up in September. Cars park along Storgatan and it's chaos during Christmas and market days. A parking lot solves that.
friendly.expression_hint: Relaxed, drinking coffee from municipal porcelain

q2_options.text: Are all parties in agreement?
What does it cost and who pays?
Are there alternative locations?

outcomes.response: Most people think it's needed. The Center Party had opinions about the location but voted yes in the end.
outcomes.feedback: No controversy — flat story.
outcomes.note: The Center Party had opinions about the location but...

outcomes.response: The estimate is 800,000. State grants cover half. But it requires demolishing the Alm villa — it's been empty since Mrs. Alm passed away.
outcomes.feedback: Demolition of a culturally historic building — that could spark debate.
outcomes.note: It's been empty since Mrs

outcomes.response: It was suggested to use the gravel lot by the station but that's owned by SJ. The square was the easiest option.
outcomes.feedback: Alternatives existed but were rejected — nothing controversial.
outcomes.note: The square was the easiest option

friendly.q1_note: Cars park along Storgatan and it's chaos during...

direct.q1_response: Småstad is growing. We get four hundred extra cars at midsummer. Storgatan can't handle it. A parking lot by the square is logical.
direct.expression_hint: Counts on his fingers, points to a map on the wall

q2_options.text: Does anything need to be demolished to make room?
Who is designing and building it?
Is there opposition in the council?

outcomes.response: The Alm villa has to go. It's been empty for three years. Culturally interesting, sure — but not protected.
outcomes.feedback: The demolition of a heritage building — good angle.
outcomes.note: Not protected

outcomes.response: We're getting bids from three firms. Standard municipal procurement.
outcomes.feedback: Bureaucracy — no story.
outcomes.note: Standard municipal procurement

outcomes.response: Eva Ström from the Center Party filed a reservation. She wanted to preserve the Alm villa. But she was alone.
outcomes.feedback: A dissenting voice — could build a debate piece.
outcomes.note: Eva Ström from the Center Party filed a reservation

direct.q1_note: A parking lot by the square is logical

pressure.q1_response: Controversial? We live in a democracy. The majority voted yes. Period.
pressure.expression_hint: Taps his fingers on the table, irritated

q2_options.text: What did those who voted no say?
The Alm villa — why is it being demolished without debate?
Is it true that Björk owns land adjacent to the square?

outcomes.response: Eva Ström thought we should investigate more. She always does. The vote was 23-4.
outcomes.feedback: Clear majority — hard to make it controversial.
outcomes.note: The vote was 23-4

outcomes.response: The villa? It's been empty since Mrs. Alm passed. The roof leaks. It costs more to renovate than to demolish.
outcomes.feedback: Argument for demolition — but the cultural angle remains.
outcomes.note: It costs more to renovate than to demolish

outcomes.response: *long pause* Who told you that? *shifts in chair* Fine. Yes, the Alm villa demolition — it wasn't in the original plan. It was added AFTER the land survey. And the survey was done by Björk's brother-in-law's company. Without a public tender. The demolition alone costs 300,000 but the villa is listed as 'cultural heritage interest' in the county's registry. They skipped the heritage assessment entirely. And yes — Björk's wife owns the adjacent plot. When the parking lot goes in, that plot doubles in value. But you didn't hear that from me.
outcomes.feedback: Pressed the politician on the specific allegation — he cracked and revealed nepotistic procurement, skipped heritage assessment, and Björk's wife's land profit.
outcomes.note: Björk's wife owns adjacent land — his brother-in-law did the survey without tender

pressure.q1_note: We live in a democracy. The majority voted yes

silence.q1_response: ...Are we just going to sit here? *laughs uncertainly* Well then, ask away.
silence.expression_hint: Fiddles with his tie clip, uncomfortable with the silence

q2_options.text: Tell me about the parking decision — in your own words.
Are you satisfied with how it went?
What do people in town think?

outcomes.response: We need parking, Björk made the proposal, we voted yes. Simple matter.
outcomes.feedback: Short and nothing new.
outcomes.note: We need parking, Björk made the proposal, we voted yes

outcomes.response: Satisfied? It was necessary, I suppose. But I might have wanted to discuss the Alm villa more. It's been standing there since the 1880s.
outcomes.feedback: Even a yes-voter has doubts — that strengthens the debate angle.
outcomes.note: It's been standing there since the 1880s

outcomes.response: People want to park. Most don't care which building is in the way.
outcomes.feedback: Pragmatic but no story.
outcomes.note: Most don't care which building is in the way

silence.q1_note: Are we just going to sit here. Well then, ask away

title: The Ice Rink Running Out of Money
description: Småstad's ice rink faces closure after the municipal grant was revoked.
lead_text: The kids at the ice rink seemed shaken up. Something about the rink closing...
preview: You walked past the ice rink and saw teenagers with placards.

interview.opening_line: We close in three weeks if nothing happens. Twenty years of youth hockey — gone. *snaps his fingers*

q1_options.text: That sounds serious. Tell me, Tommy — what happened?
How big is the deficit and why was the grant revoked?
The municipality says the ice rink has poor finances. Have you been mismanaging the money?

friendly.q1_response: The municipality pulled the grant in October. 95,000 kronor per year. Without it we can't afford the electricity — the ice machine costs a fortune to run.
friendly.expression_hint: Standing in the rink wearing an overcoat, breath like steam

q2_options.text: Why was the grant revoked?
How many kids play hockey here?
Have you tried finding alternative funding?

outcomes.response: The recreation board said the money was needed for 'other activities'. You know what that was? The municipal commissioner's conference trip to Båstad. It was in the official records.
outcomes.feedback: Reallocation to a conference trip — good contrast angle.
outcomes.note: The municipal commissioner's conference trip to Båstad

outcomes.response: Sixty kids. Three teams. Plus the hobby league for adults. And we have open skating on Sundays — at least a hundred families come to that.
outcomes.feedback: Concrete numbers — shows the community value.
outcomes.note: We have open skating on Sundays

outcomes.response: We've looked for sponsors. ICA-Per-Erik gives us a bit. And the Lions Club. But it doesn't cover the electricity costs.
outcomes.feedback: They're trying — but no new details.
outcomes.note: The Lions Club

friendly.q1_note: The ice machine costs a fortune to run

direct.q1_response: 95,000. Revoked by the recreation board. They said we didn't have sufficient 'youth activities'. We have SIXTY young people!
direct.expression_hint: Kicks the ice with his boot heel

q2_options.text: Who on the recreation board made the decision?
What did they mean by 'insufficient youth activities'?
Do you have financial records showing where the money goes?

outcomes.response: It was Ove Karlsson's proposal. He sits on the board for the Liberal Party. And his son — do you know where he plays football? At the new football hall that GOT the money.
outcomes.feedback: Reallocation to football — conflict of interest?
outcomes.note: He sits on the board for the Liberal Party

outcomes.response: They had some checklist. We were missing evening hours on Wednesdays. WEDNESDAYS! As if that determines whether kids have somewhere to be.
outcomes.feedback: Bureaucratic justification — not very strong.
outcomes.note: We were missing evening hours on Wednesdays

outcomes.response: We have every receipt. Berit and I in the office go through everything. Most goes to electricity and machine maintenance. The rest to equipment for kids who can't afford their own.
outcomes.feedback: Transparent finances — credible organization.
outcomes.note: Berit and I in the office go through everything

direct.q1_note: Revoked by the recreation board

pressure.q1_response: Mismanaged?! I work here for FREE! All coaches are volunteers! Every krona goes to the kids!
pressure.expression_hint: Index finger pointed straight at you, voice echoing in the rink

q2_options.text: Sorry — those were the municipality's words, not mine. What's your version?
Can you show me the accounts?
Who benefits from the ice rink closing?

outcomes.response: *calms down* We received 95,000 from the municipality. 60,000 went to electricity. 20,000 to machine maintenance. 15,000 to equipment for kids who don't have any. Where's the mismanagement?
outcomes.feedback: Detailed accounting — refutes the municipality's picture.
outcomes.note: 15,000 to equipment for kids who don't have any

outcomes.response: Of course I can. Berit has every receipt since 1968. Come tomorrow and we'll show you everything.
outcomes.feedback: Offers full transparency — credible.
outcomes.note: Berit has every receipt since 1968

outcomes.response: Fine, you want the truth? Ove Karlsson's kid plays football. The new football hall got OUR money — 1.4 million redirected. And Karlsson sits on the culture and leisure committee that made the decision. He didn't recuse himself. I have the meeting minutes — there's NO conflict-of-interest declaration. But it gets worse: the football hall's construction company? Småstad Bygg. Karlsson's wife is on their board. They got the contract at 30 percent above the next bid. So taxpayer money flows from the ice rink, through the committee Karlsson controls, to a company his wife profits from. It's all documented.
outcomes.feedback: Circular corruption — committee member redirects funds to company where his wife sits on the board. Fully documented chain.
outcomes.note: Karlsson's wife is on the board of the construction company that got the contract

pressure.q1_note: Every krona goes to the kids

silence.q1_response: *looks around the empty rink* Last week this place was full of kids. Today it's just me and the ice. They know it might be over.
silence.expression_hint: Chin trembling, takes a deep breath

q2_options.text: Tell me about the kids.
What happens to them if the ice rink closes?
Why do you do this, Tommy?

outcomes.response: Little Kalle Svensson — nine years old, best player I've ever seen. Lives with his mum in the council flats. Can't afford his own equipment. We give him everything. If we close, he's out on the street.
outcomes.feedback: A human face — strong for human interest.
outcomes.note: Little Kalle Svensson

outcomes.response: They have nowhere to go. The youth center closed last year. The ice rink is the only thing left in winter. Småstad becomes a desert for the kids.
outcomes.feedback: Structural problem — good context.
outcomes.note: Småstad becomes a desert for the kids

outcomes.response: My dad built this rink in 1956. With his own hands. Volunteer work. I've been standing here since I was fifteen. It's all I have. *falls silent*
outcomes.feedback: Personal and historical depth — good portrait material.
outcomes.note: My dad built this rink in 1956

silence.q1_note: They know it might be over

title: The Dead Cat with the Note
description: A dead cat was found outside the municipal building with a handwritten note around its neck.
lead_text: Someone left a dead cat in front of the municipal building. With a note. Probably some kids messing around...
preview: Town messenger Olle mentioned it in passing by the coffee machine.
npc_title: Town messenger at the municipal building

interview.opening_line: Yeah, it was a hell of a sight. Poor cat. And the note... the note was the worst part.

q1_options.text: That sounds disturbing. What did the note say, Olle?
Exactly what did the note say and where did you find the cat?
Was it a real threat or just some prank?

friendly.q1_response: It said 'NEXT TIME IT WON'T BE A CAT'. In capital letters. Block print. And then a name — Björk.
friendly.expression_hint: Runs his hand through his hair, looks around

q2_options.text: Björk — the municipal commissioner? Was it directed at him?
What did the cat look like — did you recognize it?
Who else has seen the note?

outcomes.response: I think it was directed AT Björk. The note was sticking out of the cat's collar. Placed right in front of his parking spot, not by the entrance.
outcomes.feedback: Targeted threat against the municipal commissioner — not random.
outcomes.note: Placed right in front of his parking spot, not by the...

outcomes.response: It was a black cat. Not strangled or anything — it looked like it had been hit by a car. But someone placed it there on purpose. And the NOTE...
outcomes.feedback: Cat maybe not killed — but the message was placed deliberately.
outcomes.note: Someone placed it there on purpose

outcomes.response: Just me and Sonja at reception. But Björk himself saw it — and he was TERRIFIED. White as a sheet. Called someone right away. Not the police — someone else.
outcomes.feedback: Björk called someone who wasn't the police. He knows who it is. Burning lead.
outcomes.note: Just me and Sonja at reception

friendly.q1_note: In capital letters

direct.q1_response: In front of Björk's parking spot. Seven o'clock this morning. A dead black cat with a note wrapped around its collar: 'NEXT TIME IT WON'T BE A CAT' and then 'Björk'.
direct.expression_hint: Standing with arms crossed, looking toward the municipal building entrance

q2_options.text: Did you report it to the police?
How did Björk react?
Has anything like this happened before?

outcomes.response: No. Björk told me to throw the cat away and not talk about it. And that... well, that's what I did. Until now.
outcomes.feedback: Björk wanted to hush it up — but why? Half-facts.
outcomes.note: Björk told me to throw the cat away and not talk about...

outcomes.response: He went white in the face. Took the note. Went inside and called — not the police, because I had Janne's number right there. He called someone in Gothenburg. Closed the door.
outcomes.feedback: Björk called Gothenburg — not the police. Someone from outside who's threatening.
outcomes.note: He called someone in Gothenburg

outcomes.response: Now that you ask... last month I found a smashed window at the municipal building. Björk said it was 'the wind'. But the window was on the second floor and it had NOT been windy.
outcomes.feedback: Previous incident — pattern of threats against Björk.
outcomes.note: The window was on the second floor and it had NOT been...

direct.q1_note: A dead black cat with a note wrapped around its...

pressure.q1_response: A prank?! Someone put a DEAD CAT with a death threat in front of the municipal commissioner's spot! Is that a prank?
pressure.expression_hint: Rises to full height, eyes wide open

q2_options.text: You're right. Tell me what happened — everything you saw.
Has the police documented it?
Does Björk have enemies that you know of?

outcomes.response: I found it at half six. Black cat, note around the neck. 'NEXT TIME IT WON'T BE A CAT' and then Björk's name. Björk told me to remove it and keep quiet.
outcomes.feedback: Basic facts — but cover-up attempt.
outcomes.note: 'NEXT TIME IT WON'T BE A CAT' and then Björk's name

outcomes.response: The police? Björk forbade me from calling! Said it was 'nothing to involve the police in'. How crazy is that?
outcomes.feedback: Björk blocked the police report — strange.
outcomes.note: Said it was 'nothing to involve the police in'

outcomes.response: Enemies? *lowers his voice* I heard Björk arguing on the phone three weeks ago. With some 'Ricky' in Gothenburg. Björk said 'you'll get your money, give me time'. Then he slammed the receiver down.
outcomes.feedback: Björk owes money to a 'Ricky in Gothenburg'. The threat is connected. Deep lead.
outcomes.note: I heard Björk arguing on the phone three weeks ago

pressure.q1_note: Someone put a DEAD CAT with a death threat in front of...

silence.q1_response: *looks around* ...I shouldn't be talking about this. Björk told me to keep my mouth shut. But it's been eating at me. Poor cat.
silence.expression_hint: Whispers, leans in close

q2_options.text: You can trust me, Olle. What did the note say?
Why did Björk want you to stay quiet?
Are you worried about Björk?

outcomes.response: 'NEXT TIME IT WON'T BE A CAT'. And his name. Björk. Someone is threatening the municipal commissioner and he DOESN'T WANT the police to know.
outcomes.feedback: The threat plus the silence — something doesn't add up.
outcomes.note: Someone is threatening the municipal commissioner and...

outcomes.response: *looks around nervously* Because he knows who did it. He called a private number — Stockholm area code — not the police. Locked himself in for an hour. And Sonja at reception — she photographed the note before Björk took it. The handwriting... *swallows* ...it matches a letter that was sent to the building inspector last spring. Same block letters, same red ink. Another threat. The building inspector quit two weeks later. Moved to Gothenburg. Nobody asked why. And now the same handwriting shows up with a dead cat. Someone is systematically threatening municipal officials who get in the way. And Björk knows who.
outcomes.feedback: Patience and silence unlocked the scared messenger — matching handwriting, previous threat, building inspector fled. Organized intimidation.
outcomes.note: Sonja photographed the note — handwriting matches a threat to the building inspector who quit and fled

outcomes.response: Worried? I'm TERRIFIED. If someone threatens the municipal commissioner with dead animals — what do they do to an ordinary town messenger who talks?
outcomes.feedback: Olle's fear shows the threat feels real.
outcomes.note: If someone threatens the municipal commissioner with...

silence.q1_note: It's been eating at me

title: The Library's Last Days
description: Småstad's library faces closure following a budget decision in the municipal council.
lead_text: Letter from the librarian — she's worried the library will be shut down...
preview: Typewritten letter on municipal stationery, signed 'A concerned employee'.

interview.opening_line: I probably shouldn't be talking to the press. But... someone has to know what they're doing.

q1_options.text: Thank you for reaching out, Margareta. Tell me what's happened.
What does the budget proposal say? Is it final?
The municipality says digitalization makes the library obsolete. Do they have a point?

friendly.q1_response: They're closing us on March first. Thirteen years left until my pension and they're closing my library. 4,000 registered borrowers. Children who come here every day after school.
friendly.expression_hint: Runs her fingers along the bookshelf, eyes glistening

q2_options.text: Who made the decision and why?
What happens to the children who come here after school?
Has anyone calculated what the savings actually amount to?

outcomes.response: The cultural affairs department has to save 200,000. The library costs 180,000 to run. Björk said we were 'the easiest saving'. Thirteen years of employment — the easiest saving.
outcomes.feedback: Personal and economic — good contrast angle.
outcomes.note: The library costs 180,000 to run

outcomes.response: Fifteen children every day. At least. They do homework, read, or just SIT here because it's warm and safe. Emmy Nilsson — her mother works nights. Emmy is here until we close every evening.
outcomes.feedback: A human face — the children are the strongest argument.
outcomes.note: Emmy Nilsson

outcomes.response: They save 200,000. But do you know what the conference trip to Båstad cost? 230,000. They shut down a library to fund the municipal commissioner's conference.
outcomes.feedback: Direct link — conference vs. library. Very strong contrast.
outcomes.note: They shut down a library to fund the municipal...

friendly.q1_note: 4,000 registered borrowers

direct.q1_response: It's in the 1977 budget proposal. The cultural affairs department has to save 200,000. The library costs 180,000. That's enough. We close on March first unless the council changes its mind.
direct.expression_hint: Holds up the official memo she brought along

q2_options.text: Can I get a copy of the official memo?
Who in the cultural affairs department proposed the closure?
Have you received any formal notice?

outcomes.response: Take it. I've copied the relevant pages. Look at line four — 'alternative: closure of library branch'. They call us a branch now. We've existed since 1934.
outcomes.feedback: Document in hand — good source material.
outcomes.note: We've existed since 1934

outcomes.response: The cultural affairs board chair Ingvar Blom. He's never set foot here. I invited him three times. He never came.
outcomes.feedback: Responsible person identified — and has never visited.
outcomes.note: The cultural affairs board chair Ingvar Blom

outcomes.response: A letter. From the municipal executive office. 'In light of upcoming austerity measures...' Bureaucratic Swedish for 'you're being shut down'.
outcomes.feedback: Confirms the situation but nothing new.
outcomes.note: 'In light of upcoming austerity measures...'...

direct.q1_note: We close on March first unless the council changes its...

pressure.q1_response: Digitalization? In Småstad? We haven't even paved Björkvägen! What digitalization are they talking about?
pressure.expression_hint: Takes off her glasses, polishes them vigorously

q2_options.text: You have a point. What does the library offer that nothing else does?
Is it fair to say that borrowing has declined?
What do you think the real reason for the closure is?

outcomes.response: We're the only place where everyone is welcome. Pensioners read the newspaper. Children do homework. The Yousef immigrant family learns Swedish here every Tuesday. Close us and what's left?
outcomes.feedback: The library's social function — strong argument.
outcomes.note: The Yousef immigrant family learns Swedish here every...

outcomes.response: Borrowing went down a bit in 1975. But we have more visitors now — it's not just about books!
outcomes.feedback: Partial admission — the statistics don't fully support it.
outcomes.note: Borrowing went down a bit in 1975

outcomes.response: The real reason? Björk wants to save money for his conference and his parking lot. The library has no powerful friends in the council. We're easy to sacrifice.
outcomes.feedback: Political prioritization exposed — the library is sacrificed for prestige.
outcomes.note: The library has no powerful friends in the council

pressure.q1_note: We haven't even paved Björkvägen

silence.q1_response: *rearranges the books on the shelf* I've worked here since 1962. Fourteen years. I've watched generations learn to read in these chairs.
silence.expression_hint: Strokes her hand across a worn children's book

q2_options.text: Tell me about the library. What you want people to know.
What does Småstad lose if you close?
Is there any hope?

outcomes.response: Emil Johansson learned to read here in 1965. Now he's a teacher in Jönköping. Last week he called and asked if we still had his favorite book. We did. That's what a library IS.
outcomes.feedback: A story that captures the library's soul — strong quotes.
outcomes.note: Emil Johansson learned to read here in 1965

outcomes.response: The children. They lose the children. Emmy Nilsson who's here every evening. The Yousef brothers who read Pippi in Swedish. The pensioners whose only social contact is here.
outcomes.feedback: Concrete consequences — good source material.
outcomes.note: The Yousef brothers who read Pippi in Swedish

outcomes.response: *quiet for a long time* Hope? No. Because it was never about saving money. *takes out a folder* I've worked here for 32 years. I read every budget document. The library costs 200,000. The conference trip to Båstad cost 230,000. But listen to this: when the library closes, this building — which the municipality owns — transfers to a private company. Småstad Fastighets AB. Below market rate. And the commissioner's husband sits on that company's board. The transfer agreement was signed in June. Three months BEFORE the budget vote. They're not closing a library. They're handing a building to the commissioner's family.
outcomes.feedback: Silence let the librarian reveal 32 years of careful observation — the closure is a front for transferring public property to the commissioner's family.
outcomes.note: The building transfers to Småstad Fastighets AB — commissioner's husband on the board, deal signed before the vote

silence.q1_note: I've worked here since 1962

outcomes.response: Fear. The factory is the biggest employer. 180 jobs. If it closes, Småstad dies. Everyone knows that. So people cough, vomit, get numbness — and go back to work. The insurance agency caseworker never asks questions either.

outcomes.response: Birger tried. Dahl laughed and said 'This isn't a petting zoo, it's a port.' But here's the thing — Dahl just signed a contract with Göteborgs Hamn AB to take over operations. The cats are the least of it. He's privatizing the whole harbor and nobody knows.
outcomes.feedback: The cats are a symptom — the real story is harbor privatization. Huge.
outcomes.note: Dahl signed privatization contract with Göteborgs Hamn AB

friendly.q1_note: They've been here twenty years, keep rats away

direct.q1_response: Hans Dahl, harbor master. Official reason: 'sanitary concerns'. Unofficial reason: a Gothenburg shipping executive visited last week and saw a cat on a loading pallet.
direct.expression_hint: Shrugs matter-of-factly

q2_options.text: Has the harbor done a health assessment?
Can I see the order? Is it documented?
What will happen to the rats without the cats?

outcomes.response: No assessment. No vet consulted. Just a memo from Dahl to 'resolve the feral animal situation by Friday'. That's his idea of process.
outcomes.feedback: No process followed, but a thin story on its own.
outcomes.note: No health assessment or vet consultation

outcomes.response: It's pinned on the break room board. I can show you. It says 'by order of the harbor master, effective immediately'. No consultation with workers or the health board.
outcomes.feedback: Documented proof of unilateral decision — bypassing required process.
outcomes.note: Order posted without health board consultation

outcomes.response: The grain stores will be infested within a month. We'll spend more on rat poison than we ever spent on cat food. But Dahl doesn't think that far ahead.
outcomes.feedback: Practical argument but not a strong news angle.
outcomes.note: Grain stores will be infested without cats

direct.q1_note: Gothenburg executive complained about hygiene

pressure.q1_response: Investors? I... maybe. There's been talk about the harbor changing ownership. But I'm a dock worker, not a businessman.

q2_options.text: What kind of ownership changes? Who's buying?
The workers deserve to know if their harbor is being sold. Are you going to stay quiet?
Hans Dahl isn't doing this for hygiene. What has he been up to lately?

outcomes.response: I heard — this is just what I heard — that Göteborgs Hamn AB is interested in taking over port operations. Dahl's been having lunch with their people at Hotel Strand.
outcomes.feedback: Privatization rumor with specific details. Worth investigating.
outcomes.note: Göteborgs Hamn AB interested, Dahl dining with them

outcomes.response: I'm not staying quiet, am I? I'm talking to you. But the cats are the issue. Write about the cats.
outcomes.feedback: He wants the story small. You missed the bigger picture.
outcomes.note: Wants focus on cats, not politics

outcomes.response: Dahl's the harbor master. He does what he does. Leave me out of the politics. I just want the cats to live.
outcomes.feedback: Pushed too hard on the wrong topic. He came about cats, not corruption.
outcomes.note: Refuses to discuss harbor politics

pressure.q1_note: Talk about harbor changing ownership

silence.q1_response: ...You're not going to ask? Fine. I'll tell you what I think. I think the cats are the canary in the coal mine. Everything that makes this harbor human is being stripped away.
silence.expression_hint: Grows more passionate in the silence

q2_options.text: What else is being stripped away?
Tell me about the harbor. What it was and what it's becoming.
Why does this matter so much to you personally?

outcomes.response: The break room is closing. The Christmas bonus was cancelled. And now the cats. You know why? Because Dahl is preparing the harbor for sale. I saw the brochure on his desk — 'Modern Port Operations by Göteborgs Hamn AB.' Our harbor, sold to a Gothenburg company. And none of us were told.
outcomes.feedback: Through silence, he connected the dots himself. Cats → privatization → worker betrayal. Complete story.
outcomes.note: Saw privatization brochure on Dahl's desk

outcomes.response: It was a place where men could work with dignity. Old Göran and the cats. Coffee in the break room. Now it's all efficiency reports and Gothenburg suits. We're numbers now.
outcomes.feedback: Emotional portrait of a workplace losing its soul. Good texture.
outcomes.note: Harbor losing its human character

outcomes.response: My father worked this harbor for forty years. He used to say the cats were the soul of the place. If they go... I don't know. Feels like the harbor dies too.
outcomes.feedback: Personal but not newsworthy beyond a feature piece.
outcomes.note: Father worked the harbor forty years

silence.q1_note: Everything human is being stripped away

title: The Rusted Railing
description: Safety railings at the loading dock haven't been replaced despite three incident reports.
lead_text: The railing on dock 4 is rusted through. Third report filed. Nothing done.
preview: Anonymous maintenance report left in the newsroom mailbox.

interview.opening_line: I filed three work orders this year. Three. Each time the same answer: 'budget pending'. Meanwhile a man fell off dock 4 last month and broke his collarbone.

q1_options.text: That must be frustrating. Three reports and nothing done?
Show me what's wrong with the railing. I want specifics.
Someone broke their collarbone because of this. Isn't that criminal negligence?

friendly.q1_response: Frustrating isn't the word. I'm the one who has to look at that railing every day knowing someone could go over. And when they do, it'll be my signature on the report saying it was flagged.
friendly.expression_hint: Grips his wrench tighter, jaw tightening

q2_options.text: Who receives the work orders? Where does the chain break?
Tell me about the man who fell. What happened exactly?
Do you have copies of the three reports?

outcomes.response: I send them to facilities management. Facilities sends them to finance. Finance sends them to Bergström's office. And Bergström's office sends them to the bottom of a pile. The whole system is designed to lose paperwork.
outcomes.feedback: You mapped the negligence chain all the way to the director. Structural failure.
outcomes.note: Reports go from facilities to finance to Bergström's office — designed to lose paperwork

outcomes.response: Arne Andersson. Slipped on ice, grabbed the railing, railing gave way. Fell four meters onto concrete. He was off work for six weeks. Nobody even visited him.
outcomes.feedback: You got the human story but not the systemic problem.
outcomes.note: Arne Andersson fell four meters, off work six weeks

outcomes.response: Three copies. Dated and stamped. And I have the responses — two form letters saying 'under review' and one that says 'maintenance budget allocated to priority projects'. You know what the priority project was? Repainting the executive parking lot.
outcomes.feedback: Documentary proof: three reports ignored, money spent on cosmetics instead. Gold.
outcomes.note: Maintenance budget went to repainting executive parking lot

friendly.q1_note: My signature on the report saying it was flagged

direct.q1_response: Come look. *leads you outside* See that? You can push your finger through the metal. It's like wet cardboard. The posts are barely connected to the concrete.
direct.expression_hint: Shows you firsthand, tapping the railing

q2_options.text: How long has it been like this?
Are other safety installations also in this condition?
What would a replacement cost?

outcomes.response: Since at least April. It was already bad in the winter but the rust accelerated in the spring rain. By summer it was a death trap.
outcomes.feedback: Timeline established but no accountability.
outcomes.note: Dangerous since at least April

outcomes.response: The fire extinguishers on level 2 expired in March. The emergency exit on the east side has been locked shut for six months — 'to prevent theft'. If there's a fire, people will die.
outcomes.feedback: Pattern of safety failures beyond just the railing. Systemic neglect.
outcomes.note: Fire extinguishers expired, emergency exit locked shut

outcomes.response: Maybe 2,000 kronor for materials. I could do the labor myself. But they won't approve it. Two thousand kronor to save someone's life — and they say 'budget pending'.
outcomes.feedback: Cost is trivial, making the neglect worse. But thin for a splash.
outcomes.note: Replacement cost: 2,000 kronor

direct.q1_note: You can push your finger through the metal

pressure.q1_response: Criminal? Maybe. But who's going to prosecute? The safety inspector plays cards with the factory manager every Thursday.

q2_options.text: Are you saying the safety inspector isn't doing his job?
If someone dies because of this railing, who is responsible?
Why haven't the workers filed a collective complaint through the union?

outcomes.response: He did one inspection this year. Spent twenty minutes. Signed off on everything. I watched him — he didn't even go to dock 4. Just walked through zone A and ticked every box.
outcomes.feedback: Safety inspector rubber-stamping without actual inspection. Corruption angle.
outcomes.note: Inspector spent twenty minutes, didn't visit dock 4

outcomes.response: Legally? The company. Practically? Nobody. It'll be an 'accident'. Like Arne's fall was an 'accident'. Like everything here is an 'accident'.
outcomes.feedback: Cynicism but no evidence.
outcomes.note: Everything is called an 'accident'

outcomes.response: The union? Pettersson? He plays golf with management. The union here protects itself, not us.
outcomes.feedback: Union criticism but no proof of safety cover-up.
outcomes.note: Union protects itself, not workers

pressure.q1_note: Safety inspector plays cards with factory manager

silence.q1_response: *long pause* You know what keeps me up at night? The next person who grabs that railing won't break a collarbone. They'll die. And everyone will act surprised.
silence.expression_hint: Voice drops, deadly serious

q2_options.text: What would you need to happen to prevent that?
Show me what you have. The reports, the photos, everything.
Why did you come to the paper instead of the police?

outcomes.response: Someone with authority to say 'fix it'. Not a memo. Not a form. Just someone who cares enough to spend 2,000 kronor.
outcomes.feedback: Heartfelt but no ammunition for the story.
outcomes.note: Needs someone with authority to act

outcomes.response: Here. Three work orders. Two responses. And these photos I took last week — you can see the rust, the broken welds, the concrete crumbling. All dated.
outcomes.feedback: Full documentation trail. Photos + reports + dates.
outcomes.note: Photos showing rust, broken welds, crumbling concrete — all dated

outcomes.response: Because the police would call the safety inspector. And the safety inspector would call Bergström. And Bergström would call my boss. And I'd be out by Monday. *pause* But I kept a logbook. Every deficiency I've reported for three years. Forty-seven items. Only six were fixed. The rest — 'budget pending'. I have the whole record at home.
outcomes.feedback: Three years of documented negligence. 47 reports, 6 fixed. This isn't one railing — it's systemic.
outcomes.note: Logbook: 47 deficiency reports in 3 years, only 6 fixed

silence.q1_note: The next person will die

title: The Factory Road
description: A new municipal road was built that only seems to serve the factory director's private estate.
lead_text: They built a road for one man. Taxpayer money. For one man's driveway.
preview: Municipal planning document found in a council committee appendix.

interview.opening_line: The Lindvägen extension? It was approved through normal channels. I don't see what the issue is.

q1_options.text: I'm sure you followed procedure, Bengt. Can you walk me through how this road was planned?
The road ends at Rolf Bergström's property. Who requested the extension?
Public funds for a private road to the factory director's estate. How do you explain that?

friendly.q1_response: Of course. It was part of the 1974 infrastructure plan. The committee approved it in March. It serves... the area.
friendly.expression_hint: Too rehearsed, straightens his glasses

q2_options.text: How many residents live along the extended road?
Who sits on the infrastructure committee that approved it?
Was there a public consultation before the decision?

outcomes.response: Well... currently, it's... the Bergström estate is the only property. But there are plans for future development. Eventually. The committee felt it was forward-thinking.
outcomes.feedback: He admitted only one property is served. 'Forward-thinking' — wonderful euphemism.
outcomes.note: Only the Bergström estate is currently served by the road

outcomes.response: The committee... *adjusts glasses nervously* ...Bergström's wife Karin sits on the infrastructure committee. She recused herself for the vote, technically. But she presented the proposal. And the cost estimate. And the route map.
outcomes.feedback: Conflict of interest: director's wife proposed, designed, and priced her own road. Perfect.
outcomes.note: Bergström's wife sits on the committee, presented the proposal herself

outcomes.response: Public consultation? For a road extension? That's not required for projects under 500,000 kronor.
outcomes.feedback: He's hiding behind procedure. You didn't crack it.
outcomes.note: No public consultation required for projects under 500,000 kr

friendly.q1_note: Part of the 1974 infrastructure plan

direct.q1_response: The extension was requested by... the infrastructure committee. As part of area development. Mr. Bergström's property happens to be along the route.
direct.expression_hint: Choosing words very carefully

q2_options.text: What was the total cost of the road extension?
Were alternative routes considered?
Is Bergström connected to anyone on the committee?

outcomes.response: The total cost was 340,000 kronor. For 1.2 kilometers of asphalt. That's within normal per-kilometer pricing.
outcomes.feedback: Cost figures but no scandal angle.
outcomes.note: 340,000 kronor for 1.2 km

outcomes.response: Alternative? No. The route was... determined by the terrain. *pause* Look, I just draw the maps. The committee decides.
outcomes.feedback: No alternatives considered for a road serving one property. Suspicious.
outcomes.note: No alternative routes considered

outcomes.response: Connected? Well, his wife Karin is on the committee. But she... declared a conflict of interest. On paper.
outcomes.feedback: Conflict of interest confirmed, but 'on paper' suggests it's a formality.
outcomes.note: Wife Karin on committee, declared conflict 'on paper'

direct.q1_note: Bergström's property 'happens to be' along the route

pressure.q1_response: That's a very loaded characterization. The road serves the Lindvägen area. The fact that a prominent citizen lives there doesn't make it corrupt.

q2_options.text: How many other citizens live on Lindvägen?
If this road is legitimate, you won't mind me seeing the committee minutes?
Bengt, are you comfortable putting your name on this if it comes out?

outcomes.response: Currently... one household. But the zoning plan allows for up to twelve plots. In the future. Theoretically.
outcomes.feedback: One household. 340,000 kronor. The numbers speak for themselves.
outcomes.note: Currently one household on the road, zoning allows future development

outcomes.response: The minutes are public record. You're welcome to request them through the registrar. I have nothing to hide.
outcomes.feedback: He's stonewalling you with procedure.
outcomes.note: Minutes available through public records

outcomes.response: I followed procedure. My conscience is clear. Now if you'll excuse me, I have a site visit.
outcomes.feedback: He's done talking. You got nothing explosive.
outcomes.note: Claims he followed procedure

pressure.q1_note: A prominent citizen doesn't make it corrupt

silence.q1_response: ...*fidgets* Listen, I'm a civil servant. I do what the committee tells me. If you want to know why that road exists, ask the committee.
silence.expression_hint: Growing uncomfortable in the silence

q2_options.text: What would the committee say if I asked them?
You seem uncomfortable, Bengt. What aren't you telling me?
Did anyone on the committee benefit personally from this road?

outcomes.response: They'd say exactly what I said. Infrastructure plan. Area development. Future housing. The official story.
outcomes.feedback: He's repeating the party line. You didn't break through.
outcomes.note: Repeats the official story

outcomes.response: I'm not uncomfortable. I'm... look, between us? I flagged this internally. I wrote a memo saying the cost-benefit was questionable. I was told to proceed. That's all I can say.
outcomes.feedback: He flagged it and was overruled. Internal dissent documented.
outcomes.note: Wrote internal memo questioning cost-benefit, told to proceed

outcomes.response: *closes door* Karin Bergström drew the original route map. Before the committee meeting. Before any feasibility study. The route was decided before the process even started. I have the original sketch with her handwriting on it. Date-stamped three months before the committee 'approved' it.
outcomes.feedback: Pre-decided route, director's wife's handwriting, months before formal approval. The whole process was a sham.
outcomes.note: Karin Bergström's handwritten route map dated 3 months before committee approval

silence.q1_note: Do what the committee tells me

title: The Fishing Club
description: The local fishing club has lost access to their stretch of river due to factory pollution.
lead_text: We haven't been able to fish the Industriån for two years. The water is dead.
preview: Letter from the fishing club chairman, handwritten on club stationery.

interview.opening_line: Forty years I've fished this river. My father before me. Now the trout are gone and the water smells like ammonia.

q1_options.text: Forty years is a long relationship with a river. When did things start to change?
What's killing the fish? Is it the chemical plant upstream?
The municipality says the water quality is within acceptable limits. Is that accurate?

friendly.q1_response: The trout started disappearing around '72. First the big ones. Then the minnows. By last summer you couldn't find anything alive downstream from the chemical plant.
friendly.expression_hint: Staring at the water, voice flattening

q2_options.text: Have you tested the water yourself?
What's the club doing about it? Any formal complaints?
Does the chemical plant acknowledge any responsibility?

outcomes.response: We complained to the county board last spring. They said they'd send an inspector. That was fourteen months ago.
outcomes.feedback: Bureaucratic inaction confirmed but no evidence of what's in the water.
outcomes.note: County board promised inspector fourteen months ago, never came

outcomes.response: A teacher at the school — he's a hobby chemist — tested it for us. High levels of ammonia and something he called phenol compounds. He said it's industrial waste. Definitely not natural.
outcomes.feedback: Independent water test with chemical identification. Strong supporting evidence.
outcomes.note: Teacher found high ammonia and phenol compounds — industrial waste

outcomes.response: Acknowledge? They won't even meet with us. Their factory manager said we're 'hobbyists with an agenda'. Forty years and I'm a hobbyist.
outcomes.feedback: Dismissive attitude from the plant but no hard evidence.
outcomes.note: Chemical plant calls fishing club 'hobbyists with an agenda'

friendly.q1_note: Trout disappeared around '72, water smells like ammonia

direct.q1_response: The chemical plant. Industrikemin AB. Their discharge pipe runs straight into the river about 800 meters upstream from our fishing grounds.
direct.expression_hint: Points upstream, matter-of-fact

q2_options.text: Does the plant have a permit for river discharge?
Is there any other possible source of contamination?
How many people are affected beyond the fishing club?

outcomes.response: They have a permit from 1968. It allows 'treated wastewater' discharge. But treated? I've seen the pipe. The water coming out is yellow-brown. That's not treated.
outcomes.feedback: 1968 permit for 'treated' water vs visible untreated discharge. Permit violation angle.
outcomes.note: 1968 permit allows 'treated wastewater' but discharge is yellow-brown

outcomes.response: There's a small dairy upstream, but they've been there for decades without issue. It's the chemical plant. Everyone knows.
outcomes.feedback: Common knowledge but no hard proof.
outcomes.note: Only the chemical plant is the new factor

outcomes.response: The allotment gardens downstream — families grow vegetables there, water them from the river. Children play by the banks in summer. It's not just about fish.
outcomes.feedback: Human impact angle but no documentation.
outcomes.note: Families grow food using river water, children play by the banks

direct.q1_note: Discharge pipe 800 meters upstream

pressure.q1_response: Acceptable limits? What limits? They haven't tested the water since 1971. I requested the data through the county board — they said it was 'archived'.

q2_options.text: Can you prove the water hasn't been tested?
Who at the county board handled your request?
What do the 'archived' results from 1971 show?

outcomes.response: I have the letter. I wrote to them. They wrote back saying they 'cannot locate current monitoring data'. Make of that what you will.
outcomes.feedback: Admission of missing data but not explosive.
outcomes.note: County board 'cannot locate current monitoring data'

outcomes.response: A clerk named Gunvor Ek. She was helpful at first but then went quiet. Called me back a week later and said 'I've been told to direct all inquiries to the county environmental officer'. I haven't heard back since.
outcomes.feedback: A clerk was told to stop helping. Internal silencing. Good lead.
outcomes.note: Clerk Gunvor Ek told to redirect inquiries, went quiet

outcomes.response: That's the thing. The 1971 results SHOULD show the water was already contaminated. A former county inspector I know — now retired — told me that the results were 'adjusted' before filing. The original readings were double the permitted levels. Someone changed the numbers.
outcomes.feedback: Falsified water quality data from a retired insider. If you can verify this, it's massive.
outcomes.note: Retired inspector says 1971 results were 'adjusted' — original readings double the limit

pressure.q1_note: Haven't tested since 1971, data 'archived'

silence.q1_response: ...My grandson asked me last summer why we don't fish anymore. I didn't know what to tell him. How do you explain to a seven-year-old that someone poisoned his river?
silence.expression_hint: Old eyes wet, staring at the empty water

q2_options.text: What would you want your grandson to know about this river?
Who poisoned it, Lars-Erik?
What are you afraid will happen if nobody writes about this?

outcomes.response: That it used to be alive. That his great-grandfather caught salmon here. That this town used to care about something besides production quotas.
outcomes.feedback: Beautiful personal story but not a news piece.
outcomes.note: Great-grandfather caught salmon here

outcomes.response: Industrikemin AB. And the county that let them do it. And the municipality that looks the other way because the plant employs 300 people. Everyone's complicit.
outcomes.feedback: He named the whole system. Multiple actor accountability.
outcomes.note: Chemical plant, county, and municipality all complicit

outcomes.response: That the children get sick. The allotment gardens downstream — three families had to stop growing because the vegetables tasted wrong. And little Maja from Strandgatan... she had rashes all summer after swimming. The doctor said 'eczema'. But I've seen that water. That's not eczema. That's poison.
outcomes.feedback: Children's health affected. Medical dismissal of symptoms. This elevates from environmental to public health.
outcomes.note: Children with rashes after swimming, doctor misdiagnosed as 'eczema'

silence.q1_note: How do you explain to a seven-year-old
