title: The Workers' Field
description: The factory sports field where workers play football is being sold for factory expansion.
lead_text: They're tearing up our football pitch. Bergström wants to build a new loading bay.
preview: Angry young apprentice corners you outside the library.

interview.opening_line: That field is the only good thing about working here. Every Wednesday and Saturday we play. Now they're turning it into concrete for trucks.

q1_options.text: Sounds like the field means a lot to the workers. Tell me about it.
When was the decision made and who approved the sale?
Is it true the workers were never consulted about losing their sports field?

friendly.q1_response: It's where the old-timers teach us youngsters. Where foremen forget they're foremen. We even got our rival match against the shipyard team. It's the one place at work where you're a person, not a number.
friendly.expression_hint: Animated, hands moving as he describes plays

q2_options.text: Who decided to sell the field? Was it Bergström directly?
What do the older workers say about losing it?
Is there anywhere else the team could play?

outcomes.response: Bergström said it at the quarterly meeting. Didn't even discuss it. Just said 'the sports field will be repurposed for operational expansion effective January'. Like it was nothing. Forty years of football — nothing.
outcomes.feedback: Unilateral decision, no discussion. Management dismissing workers' culture.
outcomes.note: Bergström announced it at quarterly meeting, no discussion

outcomes.response: Old Lennart cried. First time I've ever seen that man show emotion. He said 'they're taking the last thing that makes this place bearable.'
outcomes.feedback: Emotional but not newsworthy beyond a feature.
outcomes.note: Old worker cried — 'last thing that makes this place bearable'

outcomes.response: The municipal pitch is booked solid and costs money. We can't afford it on apprentice wages. Without the factory field, the team dies.
outcomes.feedback: No alternatives exist, but thin for a news story.
outcomes.note: No affordable alternative venue exists

friendly.q1_note: One place where you're a person, not a number

direct.q1_response: The board decided in October. Nobody told the workers until last week. Bergström put up a notice on the canteen wall — 'field closing December 15'. That's how we found out.
direct.expression_hint: Shows you a crumpled photocopy of the notice

q2_options.text: Was the workers' council informed before the notice went up?
What's the land worth? Is this about real estate?
Is the loading bay expansion actually needed?

outcomes.response: Workers' council? Nobody asked us anything. We found out from a piece of paper taped to a wall.
outcomes.feedback: Bypassed consultation but a familiar complaint.
outcomes.note: Workers' council not consulted

outcomes.response: Funny you ask. The field is right next to the main road. A loading bay there? Makes no logistical sense. But a car dealership or a petrol station? That makes a lot of financial sense. Someone told me Bergström got an offer for the land.
outcomes.feedback: The loading bay might be a cover story. Real motive: land sale for profit.
outcomes.note: Loading bay doesn't make logistic sense, Bergström may have received an offer for the land

outcomes.response: Do they need more loading capacity? Sure. But there's empty land on the south side of the factory. They chose the field because it's easier. Or cheaper. Or both.
outcomes.feedback: Alternative locations exist but you didn't uncover the real motive.
outcomes.note: Empty land on south side could be used instead

direct.q1_note: Board decided in October, workers told last week

pressure.q1_response: Consulted? Ha! When has this company ever consulted workers about anything? We're equipment to them. Interchangeable parts.

q2_options.text: The union should have fought this. Where are they?
Are the workers going to do anything about it?
Is it true Bergström plans to sell the land commercially?

outcomes.response: Pettersson at the union? He's useless. Shook his head, said 'it's management prerogative'. That's his answer to everything.
outcomes.feedback: Union abdicating responsibility but no unique angle.
outcomes.note: Union boss said 'management prerogative'

outcomes.response: Some boys are talking about a work-to-rule protest. No overtime, no voluntary shifts, strict breaks. If they take our field, we take their flexibility.
outcomes.feedback: Workers planning collective action — potential followup story.
outcomes.note: Workers planning work-to-rule protest

outcomes.response: Sell it? I wouldn't put it past him, but I don't know for sure. You'd have to check the land registry.
outcomes.feedback: Speculation only.
outcomes.note: Doesn't know about commercial sale plans for certain

pressure.q1_note: We're equipment to them, interchangeable parts

silence.q1_response: ...I'm nineteen. I started here because my dad worked here. He played on that field. And now they're killing it and nobody cares.
silence.expression_hint: Voice breaking slightly, trying to hold it together

q2_options.text: What would your dad say about this?
Why does nobody care? What's stopping people from fighting?
You care. That's why you're talking to me. What do you want people to know?

outcomes.response: He'd say fight it. But he's not here anymore. Died in the mill two years ago. Heart attack on the factory floor. They sent flowers.
outcomes.feedback: Deeply personal but doesn't advance the field story.
outcomes.note: Father died on the factory floor two years ago

outcomes.response: Because everyone's afraid. Afraid of losing shifts, afraid of being the troublemaker. Bergström doesn't fire you — he just gives you the worst assignments until you quit. That's how he works.
outcomes.feedback: Pattern of corporate intimidation. Strong context.
outcomes.note: Bergström gives worst assignments to troublemakers until they quit

outcomes.response: I want them to know that this field was built by workers in 1935. With their own hands, on their own time. The company never paid for it. It's OUR field, not theirs. And I found the deed — it's registered to the Workers' Athletic Association, not to Ståhlbergs Stålverk. Bergström is selling land he doesn't own.
outcomes.feedback: Bombshell — the land is legally owned by the workers' association, not the company. Bergström has no right to sell it.
outcomes.note: Deed shows field registered to Workers' Athletic Association, not the company

silence.q1_note: Nobody cares

title: The Veterans' Day
description: Retired factory workers' annual reunion reveals names that were erased from company history.
lead_text: They took our photos off the wall. Thirty years of service and now we don't exist.
preview: Handwritten letter from a retired worker, shaky handwriting.

interview.opening_line: Every year we meet at Folkets Hus. Fewer of us each time. But this year — they removed our photos from the factory hall. Thirty years of service portraits. Just gone.

q1_options.text: That must hurt, Lennart. Those photos represent your life's work.
Who ordered the photos removed and why?
Is it true they're erasing workers who filed safety complaints?

friendly.q1_response: Thirty-two years I gave to that mill. Started at sixteen. And now some new manager decides the entrance hall needs to be 'modernized'. Our faces don't fit the new image.
friendly.expression_hint: Holding a faded photograph of himself as a young worker

q2_options.text: What happened to the photos? Were they destroyed?
How do the other retirees feel about this?
Did anyone from the company explain the decision?

outcomes.response: I went to the factory to look. Found them in a skip behind the loading dock. Thirty years of portraits in a rubbish pile. I pulled mine out. And Göran's — he died last spring. His widow doesn't know yet. I can't tell her.
outcomes.feedback: Portraits literally trashed. Göran's widow angle adds devastating emotional weight.
outcomes.note: Photos found in rubbish skip behind loading dock, including dead colleague's

outcomes.response: Åke is furious. Bengt won't stop talking about it. But we're old men. What are we going to do? Write an angry letter? We already did.
outcomes.feedback: Collective indignation but no news hook.
outcomes.note: Retirees wrote angry letter, no response

outcomes.response: Nobody explained anything. I called the switchboard. They transferred me three times. Finally someone said 'the hall is being renovated'. Renovated. That's what they call throwing us away.
outcomes.feedback: Bureaucratic dismissal but no larger pattern.
outcomes.note: Company said hall is being 'renovated'

friendly.q1_note: Our faces don't fit the new image

direct.q1_response: The new PR manager. Erika something. She's making the factory 'modern and forward-looking'. That's the actual quote from the newsletter.
direct.expression_hint: Tapping the bench with his cane

q2_options.text: Were all veteran photos removed, or only specific ones?
What's replacing the portraits?
Has the company acknowledged the veterans' service in any other way?

outcomes.response: Only the ones from the union era. The old ones — from before the union was formed in '47 — those stayed. And the management portraits from every era. So workers who organized are erased. Workers who obeyed are kept. Managers forever. You see the pattern?
outcomes.feedback: Selective erasure — union-era workers removed, pre-union and management kept. Ideological purge of labor history.
outcomes.note: Only union-era worker portraits removed, pre-union and management portraits kept

outcomes.response: Abstract art. Metal sculptures. 'Dynamic industry in motion' or some PR nonsense. Modern.
outcomes.feedback: Flavor detail but no news angle.
outcomes.note: Replaced by abstract art and metal sculptures

outcomes.response: Acknowledged? They stopped the annual retirement dinner two years ago. No pension ceremony. No gold watch. You just... stop coming.
outcomes.feedback: Pattern of disrespect but thin for a story.
outcomes.note: Annual retirement dinner cancelled two years ago

direct.q1_note: New PR manager making factory 'modern'

pressure.q1_response: Safety complaints? I... I wouldn't know about that. I just know they took our pictures down. All of us. After decades.

q2_options.text: Lennart, I've heard that workers who challenged management are being erased from history. Is that what's happening?
Did you ever file a complaint during your years at the factory?
What happened to the workers who spoke up?

outcomes.response: I don't know about 'erased'. They took down photos. It's disrespectful. That's all I know.
outcomes.feedback: He won't make the connection you're pushing for.
outcomes.note: Doesn't connect photo removal to complaints

outcomes.response: I filed one. In 1961. About ventilation in the cutting room. They fixed it — took two years, but they fixed it. My photo was still up last year. Now it's gone.
outcomes.feedback: A complaint-filer whose portrait was removed. But he can't prove causation.
outcomes.note: Filed safety complaint in 1961, photo removed

outcomes.response: Some got transferred. Some got the bad shifts. One man — Olle Falk — they promoted him to a job he didn't want, far from his family. He quit within a year. That was the point.
outcomes.feedback: Historical intimidation pattern but second-hand.
outcomes.note: Workers who spoke up were transferred or promoted out

pressure.q1_note: I wouldn't know about safety complaints

silence.q1_response: ...*looks down at his hands* These hands built that factory. Literally. I poured concrete for the eastern wing in '48. And now they throw my face in the rubbish.
silence.expression_hint: Studying his weathered hands, profound sadness

q2_options.text: What would you want young workers today to know?
What does this factory owe the people who built it?
Take your time, Lennart. I'm listening.

outcomes.response: That we existed. That real people, with real families, built every beam and poured every floor. We weren't just labor costs on a spreadsheet.
outcomes.feedback: Dignity statement. Moving but not news.
outcomes.note: We existed, we weren't labor costs on a spreadsheet

outcomes.response: It owes us respect. And pensions that aren't being eroded by inflation while the directors get raises. Ingvar at the union — useless. He agreed to the pension freeze without telling us. We found out from the bank.
outcomes.feedback: Pension freeze agreed without worker consent — that's a story.
outcomes.note: Union agreed to pension freeze without telling retirees

outcomes.response: *long silence* I brought something. *opens a worn folder* Every year-end bonus report from 1950 to 1972. The workers' share has gone from 12% of profits to 1.4%. In the same period, the board's share went from 3% to 18%. Every year they take more from us and give more to themselves. These photos? It's just the latest thing they've stolen.
outcomes.feedback: Twenty-two years of profit-sharing data showing systematic wealth transfer from workers to management. The photos are a symbol — the data is the story.
outcomes.note: Year-end bonus: workers went from 12% to 1.4% of profits, board from 3% to 18%

silence.q1_note: These hands built that factory

title: The Strike Threat
description: Paper mill workers threaten a symbolic one-day strike over broken overtime promises.
lead_text: They promised us time-and-a-half for weekend shifts. It's been six months. We got nothing.
preview: Anonymous letter from the paper mill union branch.

interview.opening_line: Six months since the overtime agreement. Not a single extra krona. Management says 'administrative delays'. The boys are done waiting.

q1_options.text: That's a long time to wait, Folke. How are the workers handling it?
What exactly was agreed and do you have the signed agreement?
Some say the union leadership already took a deal and isn't telling the members. True?

friendly.q1_response: They're angry. But quiet angry — the dangerous kind. Men with families who've been working every Saturday for six months without the pay they were promised.
friendly.expression_hint: Solid as a wall, controlled fury

q2_options.text: What's the total unpaid overtime across all workers?
Have you confronted management about breaking the agreement?
What happens if the strike actually goes ahead?

outcomes.response: I calculated it. 340 workers, average 4 unpaid weekend shifts each. At the agreed rate, the company owes roughly 680,000 kronor. That's money in workers' pockets that the company is sitting on.
outcomes.feedback: Hard number — 680,000 kronor owed. Concrete and publishable.
outcomes.note: Company owes approximately 680,000 kronor in unpaid overtime

outcomes.response: Three times. Three meetings. Each time they say 'it's being processed'. Last time the HR director didn't even show up. Sent his secretary.
outcomes.feedback: Management contempt but no new angle.
outcomes.note: Three meetings, HR director sent secretary

outcomes.response: If we strike, they'll bring in agency workers. They've done it before. We lose a day's pay and nothing changes.
outcomes.feedback: Strategic weakness admitted but not a news angle.
outcomes.note: Strike risks replacement by agency workers

friendly.q1_note: Quiet angry — the dangerous kind

direct.q1_response: Signed agreement, March 15th. Time-and-a-half for all weekend and holiday shifts, effective April 1st. Signed by management and the union. I have my copy right here.
direct.expression_hint: Pulls out a folded paper from his jacket

q2_options.text: Can I photograph the agreement?
Who signed on behalf of management?
Has the union filed a formal dispute?

outcomes.response: Here. Read it yourself. Clause 4, paragraph 2: 'All overtime hours worked on Saturdays, Sundays, and public holidays shall be compensated at 150% of the base hourly rate, effective April 1, 1974.' Crystal clear.
outcomes.feedback: Documentary proof of the broken agreement. The clause is unambiguous.
outcomes.note: Clause 4, paragraph 2: 150% overtime rate effective April 1, 1974

outcomes.response: Rolf Bergström. Personally. His signature right there. And you know what I found out last week? Bergström sent a memo to payroll in June saying 'defer implementation until further notice'. He signed the agreement and then secretly told payroll not to honor it.
outcomes.feedback: Signed an agreement, then secretly blocked payment. Deliberate breach of contract with memo proof.
outcomes.note: Bergström signed agreement then sent secret memo to payroll to 'defer implementation'

outcomes.response: Filed it two weeks ago. Central union says it could take months. That's why the boys want to strike — they can't wait for lawyers.
outcomes.feedback: Formal process underway but no dramatic revelation.
outcomes.note: Formal dispute filed two weeks ago, could take months

direct.q1_note: Signed agreement, March 15th. Time-and-a-half

pressure.q1_response: What? No. Absolutely not. I would never sell out my members. Where did you hear that?

q2_options.text: Workers I've spoken to say Pettersson at regional level made a side deal. Know anything about that?
If the union is clean, why has it taken this long to file a dispute?
I'm just asking the questions workers are asking, Folke. They need answers.

outcomes.response: *long pause* ...Pettersson told me to 'let it cool down'. Said that with the oil crisis, we can't push too hard. But that's not his decision. The agreement is signed. The law is on our side.
outcomes.feedback: Union leadership pressuring the local branch to back down. Internal conflict.
outcomes.note: Regional union boss Pettersson told him to 'let it cool down'

outcomes.response: Because filing a dispute is a big step. You don't do it lightly. But we've done it now. And we're not backing down.
outcomes.feedback: Defensive answer. He's telling the truth but you rattled him for nothing.
outcomes.note: Formal dispute now filed, not backing down

outcomes.response: Fine. Here's my answer: we fight for every krona, every time. That's what unions do. Anyone who says otherwise doesn't know me.
outcomes.feedback: A speech, not information.
outcomes.note: Folke insists the union fights for every krona

pressure.q1_note: I would never sell out my members

silence.q1_response: ...*studies you* You're new here, aren't you. Birgit's new reporter. Alright. I'll tell you what you need to know. But you have to understand something first — this isn't just about overtime.
silence.expression_hint: Deciding whether to trust you

q2_options.text: What is it about, then?
I'm listening. Take your time.
What don't people understand about this dispute?

outcomes.response: It's about whether agreements mean anything in this town. Bergström signs papers, shakes hands, takes photos for the newsletter. Then he does whatever he wants. The overtime is just the latest. Last year he promised safety equipment upgrades — nothing. Year before, he promised a daycare subsidy — nothing. I keep a list. Seventeen broken promises in five years. All documented.
outcomes.feedback: Seventeen documented broken promises in five years. This isn't about overtime — it's about institutional lying.
outcomes.note: List of 17 broken management promises in 5 years, all documented

outcomes.response: Every time management breaks a promise and gets away with it, the workers lose a little more faith. In the company. In the union. In the system. This overtime fight — if we lose this one, the men will stop believing anything can change.
outcomes.feedback: The existential stakes for organized labor. Deep context but needs facts.
outcomes.note: If workers lose this fight, they'll stop believing in the system

outcomes.response: People think unions are greedy. We're not greedy. We're asking for what was agreed. In writing. With signatures. That's not greed — that's contract law.
outcomes.feedback: Good quote but you already knew this.
outcomes.note: Union asking for what was agreed in writing

silence.q1_note: This isn't just about overtime

title: The Worker Housing
description: Families in the factory worker housing estate are getting sick from mold and damp.
lead_text: My two boys have had a cough since September. The walls in the bedroom are black with mold.
preview: Desperate letter from a mother, water stains on the paper.

interview.opening_line: Come inside. See for yourself. I'm ashamed to show you but someone has to see what they make us live in.

q1_options.text: You shouldn't be ashamed, Gunhild. How long has the mold been this bad?
Who is responsible for maintaining these apartments?
These conditions are illegal. Has the housing company ever been inspected?

friendly.q1_response: Since last winter. The pipes froze, something leaked inside the walls, and by spring the mold was everywhere. The bathroom. The bedroom. My boys' room. The doctor says it's making them sick.
friendly.expression_hint: Shows you the bedroom, black patches on walls

q2_options.text: What did the doctor say exactly?
Have you reported it to the housing company?
Are other families in the building affected too?

outcomes.response: Chronic bronchitis for both boys. The doctor said to 'improve ventilation'. How? The windows don't open properly and we can't afford to heat with them open.
outcomes.feedback: Medical confirmation but no accountability.
outcomes.note: Both boys have chronic bronchitis, doctor said 'improve ventilation'

outcomes.response: Eleven times. I have carbon copies of every complaint. They sent a man once — he painted over the mold with white paint. It came back in two weeks. That was their 'repair'.
outcomes.feedback: Eleven documented complaints, cosmetic repair only. Pattern of neglect.
outcomes.note: 11 complaints, one repair: painted over mold, came back in 2 weeks

outcomes.response: The whole building. Fourteen apartments. Lena on the third floor — her daughter got asthma. Old Birger on the ground floor — he's been in hospital twice. And the new family, the Kovačevićs, they don't even know they can complain. They think this is normal. It's not normal.
outcomes.feedback: Building-wide health crisis. Hospital admissions. Immigrant family not knowing their rights. This is systemic.
outcomes.note: 14 apartments affected, child with asthma, elderly man hospitalized twice, immigrant family unaware of rights

friendly.q1_note: Doctor says the mold is making the boys sick

direct.q1_response: Industribostäder AB. A subsidiary of Ståhlbergs Stålverk. They own all the worker housing in Bruksgatan. My husband works at the steel mill — the apartment comes with the job.
direct.expression_hint: Pulling apartment contract from a drawer

q2_options.text: Can workers complain without risking their housing?
What does the lease say about maintenance responsibilities?
How much rent do you pay for these conditions?

outcomes.response: That's the thing. If my husband makes trouble at the factory, we risk the apartment. They don't say it outright, but everyone knows. The housing IS the leash.
outcomes.feedback: Company housing as control mechanism. Workers can't complain without risking home AND job.
outcomes.note: Housing used as control — complaining risks eviction

outcomes.response: The lease says 'landlord responsible for structural maintenance'. But there's a clause — 'tenant responsible for ventilation and surface condensation'. They use that clause to blame us for the mold.
outcomes.feedback: Contractual blame-shifting but expected.
outcomes.note: Lease clause blames tenants for 'surface condensation'

outcomes.response: 1,400 kronor a month. For a two-bedroom apartment with black mold, broken windows, and a bathroom where the tiles are falling off. Market rate for this area? Maybe 800. They overcharge us because we can't leave.
outcomes.feedback: Overcharging workers who can't leave. Captive market exploitation.
outcomes.note: Paying 1,400 kr when market rate is 800, can't leave because housing tied to job

direct.q1_note: Housing company is subsidiary of Ståhlbergs Stålverk

pressure.q1_response: Inspected? Nobody comes. We called the municipal health board once. They said they'd send someone. That was in March.

q2_options.text: Who at the health board did you speak to?
Would you let me bring a photographer to document the conditions?
What would happen if all fourteen families complained at once?

outcomes.response: A woman named Ingrid. She sounded concerned on the phone. Then nothing. I called back in May — she'd been 'transferred to another department'.
outcomes.feedback: Municipal contact transferred. Possibly silenced. But speculative.
outcomes.note: Health board contact transferred to another department

outcomes.response: You can photograph whatever you want. I have nothing to hide. Look at this wall. This ceiling. My boys' room. The world should see how Bergström's workers live.
outcomes.feedback: Open access for documentation. Photos would make this story visceral.
outcomes.note: Open to full photo documentation of conditions

outcomes.response: Some are too scared. The Lindqvists just had a baby. They can't risk losing the apartment. We tried to organize — Ulla from the tenant association helped — but most people signed anonymously.
outcomes.feedback: Fear prevents collective action. The system working as designed.
outcomes.note: Most families too scared to complain openly

pressure.q1_note: Nobody inspects these apartments

silence.q1_response: ...*sets down the cup, walks you to the children's room* Look at this wall. My boys sleep here. Every night. In this. And I can't do anything about it.
silence.expression_hint: Standing in the doorway, fists clenched

q2_options.text: Why can't you do anything?
What would it take to fix this properly?
What do the boys say about their room?

outcomes.response: Because if I push too hard, Erik loses his shifts. And if he loses shifts, we can't pay rent. And if we can't pay rent, we lose the apartment AND the job. The whole thing is a trap.
outcomes.feedback: The complete control system exposed: housing tied to job tied to silence.
outcomes.note: Push too hard → lost shifts → can't pay rent → lose apartment AND job

outcomes.response: A plumber told me — in secret, because he works for Industribostäder — that the building needs complete pipe replacement. Cost: about 40,000 kronor per apartment. 14 apartments, that's 560,000. But last year the company's annual report showed 2.3 million in profit. They can afford it. They choose not to.
outcomes.feedback: The fix costs 560,000 kr. The company made 2.3 million profit. They choose to let children get sick. Devastating.
outcomes.note: Pipe replacement costs 560,000 kr, company profit was 2.3 million — they choose not to fix it

outcomes.response: My youngest asks why they cough so much. He asks if he's sick. I say no, it's just the cold weather. I lie. Every night I lie to my children.
outcomes.feedback: Heartbreaking but not a news hook on its own.
outcomes.note: Mother lies to children about why they're sick

silence.q1_note: I can't do anything about it

title: The Office Party
description: The steel mill's annual Christmas party cost more than workers earn in a month.
lead_text: Someone left the party receipt on the canteen table. Three thousand kronor on champagne alone.
preview: A factory clerk catches your eye near the post office, holding something.

interview.opening_line: I found this on my desk. I think it was left there by mistake. The numbers... look at the numbers.

q1_options.text: That must have been quite a shock, Per-Olov. Walk me through what you see.
What's the total? Who signed off on it?
Is the company laundering money through these parties?

friendly.q1_response: I've worked here nine years. Our Christmas bonus was canceled this year. 'Austerity,' they said. Then they spent more on a single party than I make in a month.
friendly.expression_hint: Shaking his head, bitter disbelief

q2_options.text: What exactly was on the receipt? Can you list the items?
Who attended this party? Was it management only?
Has this happened before, or is this the first time?

outcomes.response: Champagne, imported cheese, cigars. It was a management dinner at Hotel Strandberg. Maybe twenty people.
outcomes.feedback: Basic party details confirmed but nothing specifically damning.
outcomes.note: Management dinner at Hotel Strandberg

outcomes.response: Three thousand kronor on champagne. Seven hundred on cigars. They rented a private dining room at Hotel Strandberg. The same month they cut the workers' Christmas bonus of 200 kronor — 'too expensive,' they said.
outcomes.feedback: Specific contrast between executive spending and worker austerity. Publishable comparison.
outcomes.note: 3000 kr champagne vs 200 kr bonus cut

outcomes.response: Here's the thing — the receipt was coded as 'equipment maintenance.' I checked the ledger. The last three quarters, 'equipment maintenance' has doubled. I think they've been hiding entertainment costs in the maintenance budget.
outcomes.feedback: Accounting fraud — entertainment disguised as equipment costs. This is bigger than a party.
outcomes.note: Entertainment hidden as 'equipment maintenance'

friendly.q1_note: Bonus canceled same year as lavish party

direct.q1_response: Twelve thousand kronor total. Director Bergström signed it. But here's the strange part — it's coded as 'equipment inspection dinner.' There was no inspection.
direct.expression_hint: Tapping the paper nervously

q2_options.text: Can I see the receipt? I need to verify the figures.
How does a twelve-thousand-kronor dinner get coded as equipment inspection?
Are there more receipts like this? Is this a pattern?

outcomes.response: I can't give it to you — they'd know it was me. But the total was twelve thousand, signed by Bergström on December 8th.
outcomes.feedback: Verbal confirmation only — no document. Hard to publish without proof.
outcomes.note: 12,000 kr signed by Bergström, Dec 8

outcomes.response: Here, look — 'Equipment Inspection Dinner, 12,340 kr.' The inspection line doesn't exist in the schedule. I checked. They invented a reason to expense it.
outcomes.feedback: Document with fabricated justification. Clear paper trail.
outcomes.note: Fictitious inspection used to justify expense

outcomes.response: I pulled four more. Same pattern every quarter — 'equipment inspection,' 'safety review dinner,' 'board consultation.' If you add them up, that's almost 50,000 kronor in fake dinners this year alone. While 300 workers lost their bonus.
outcomes.feedback: Systematic fraud with multiple documents. Front-page material.
outcomes.note: 50,000 kr in fake dinners across four quarters

direct.q1_note: 12,000 kr coded as 'equipment inspection'

pressure.q1_response: Laundering? I didn't say — I mean, it's creative accounting, not... Look, I just thought someone should know.

q2_options.text: I'm sorry. Let's slow down. What does the receipt actually show?
Creative accounting is a crime too, Per-Olov. What are you afraid of?
If this goes deeper, wouldn't you want someone to expose it?

outcomes.response: It shows a party. An expensive party. That's all I know for certain.
outcomes.feedback: He retreated. You got the minimum — an expensive party exists.
outcomes.note: Expensive party confirmed, no details

outcomes.response: Fine. Yes, I think there's something wrong. The receipt is coded as equipment maintenance. There was no maintenance. Bergström signs these every quarter.
outcomes.feedback: Pressure rattled him but he cracked. You got the miscoding angle.
outcomes.note: Quarterly miscoded expenses, Bergström signs

outcomes.response: I'll tell you what I'm afraid of — that I'll end up like Sjögren in accounts. He asked too many questions and was 'restructured' out. But yes, it's a pattern. Every quarter. And it's not just parties — there are supplier invoices from companies that don't seem to exist.
outcomes.feedback: Ghost suppliers and retribution — this is systematic fraud. He broke through the fear.
outcomes.note: Non-existent supplier invoices, previous questioner fired

pressure.q1_note: He got scared — may be bigger than a party

silence.q1_response: ... You're not going to say anything? Fine. Maybe I was stupid to come here. It's just... twelve thousand kronor. We lost our bonuses, you know.
silence.expression_hint: Shuffling the paper, talking to himself as much as you

q2_options.text: Twelve thousand. That's a lot of bonuses.
You came here for a reason, Per-Olov.
What would happen if Bergström knew you had this?

outcomes.response: Sixty bonuses. Sixty families. They could have had Christmas money instead of this party. That's the story, isn't it?
outcomes.feedback: Emotional angle but no evidence of wrongdoing beyond bad taste.
outcomes.note: 12,000 kr = 60 worker bonuses

outcomes.response: I came because it's wrong. And because this receipt says 'equipment maintenance' but it was a party. If that's not lying, what is?
outcomes.feedback: He found his conviction. The miscoding angle gives you something concrete.
outcomes.note: Receipt miscoded — party as 'equipment maintenance'

outcomes.response: He'd fire me. Like he fired Sjögren. But you know what? Sjögren was right to ask questions. There are more receipts. Supplier invoices to addresses that are just empty lots. I've been keeping copies.
outcomes.feedback: He trusts the silence. Copies of fraudulent invoices — documentary evidence.
outcomes.note: Copies of fraudulent supplier invoices kept

silence.q1_note: Twelve thousand kronor, sixty lost bonuses

title: The Night Shift
description: Night shift workers at the rolling mill say safety lights have been off for weeks.
lead_text: We work in the dark. One guy slipped on the grating last week. Foreman says it's a 'temporary situation.'
preview: A steelworker flags you down at the bus stop, still in overalls.

interview.opening_line: You from the paper? Good. Someone needs to write about this before someone dies.

q1_options.text: I appreciate you speaking up, Erik. Tell me what's happening on the night shift.
How long have the safety lights been out? Which sections?
If someone gets killed, the company will say you never reported it. Did you?

friendly.q1_response: Three weeks. The overhead lights in sections C and D went out. We reported it. Nothing happened. Then Krister Holm slipped on the grating Tuesday — fell two meters onto concrete.
friendly.expression_hint: Clenching his jaw, looking down

q2_options.text: Is Krister okay? What happened after the fall?
Did anyone document the reports you made?
What did the foreman say when you reported it?

outcomes.response: Krister bruised his ribs. Foreman told him to take a couple days off — but not to file a workplace injury report. Said it was 'Krister's own carelessness.'
outcomes.feedback: Victim exists but you only got the verbal cover-up angle.
outcomes.note: Foreman blocked injury report, blamed worker

outcomes.response: Krister cracked two ribs. He went to Dr. Lindqvist at the health center — there's a medical record. But the foreman told him not to file a workplace injury claim. And we have a logbook entry from two weeks ago reporting the lights.
outcomes.feedback: Medical record plus written safety complaint — two documents that contradict the cover-up.
outcomes.note: Medical record + logbook entry from 2 weeks ago

outcomes.response: Here's what you need to know — Krister isn't the first. Nils Forsberg fell in September. Same section, same darkness. His injury report was filed but then disappeared from the records. And the lights were reported broken in August. Three months, nothing done.
outcomes.feedback: Pattern of injuries plus vanishing reports. Systematic negligence.
outcomes.note: Second worker fell in Sept, report disappeared, lights broken since Aug

friendly.q1_note: Krister Holm fell two meters in the dark

direct.q1_response: Sections C and D of the rolling mill. Three weeks now. We put in a maintenance request on October 28th. Reference number 74-382. Nothing happened.
direct.expression_hint: Steady eye contact, counting on fingers

q2_options.text: Who handles maintenance requests? Where does 74-382 go?
Have there been any injuries in those sections since the lights went out?
Is there a safety inspector assigned to the rolling mill?

outcomes.response: Goes to the maintenance department, then to the production manager for approval. Ours is Henriksson. He approves or rejects. We never heard back.
outcomes.feedback: You know the chain of command but not why it stalled.
outcomes.note: Maintenance request to Henriksson, no response

outcomes.response: Henriksson is the production manager. He rejected the request — marked it 'non-critical.' I have a copy. And yes, Krister Holm fell Tuesday. Cracked ribs. Medical record exists at the health center.
outcomes.feedback: The rejection document plus medical evidence. Strong factual case.
outcomes.note: Request rejected as 'non-critical', injury documented

outcomes.response: Henriksson rejected it as 'non-critical.' But I checked — the budget line for safety maintenance was diverted to production targets last quarter. The money for lights went to keeping the furnace running an extra shift. And the safety inspector? He hasn't visited since June. I have the visitors' log.
outcomes.feedback: Budget diversion from safety to production plus absent inspectors. Systemic.
outcomes.note: Safety budget diverted to production, no inspector visit since June

direct.q1_note: Request 74-382, sections C and D

pressure.q1_response: Reported it? Of course we reported it! I have the damn reference number memorized — 74-382. Filed October 28th. What more do you want?

q2_options.text: Good — you did the right thing. What happened after you filed it?
So if you reported it, why is the company pretending you didn't?
Who specifically ignored request 74-382?

outcomes.response: Nothing happened. That's the point. Three weeks, nothing. And then Krister fell.
outcomes.feedback: Clear timeline but no documentation of the cover-up.
outcomes.note: Three weeks ignored, then injury

outcomes.response: Because Henriksson rejected it. Stamped it 'non-critical.' A rolling mill in the dark — 'non-critical.' One week later, Krister Holm cracks his ribs. And Henriksson tells him not to file an injury report.
outcomes.feedback: Named decision-maker plus injury suppression. Good story.
outcomes.note: Henriksson stamped 'non-critical', then blocked injury report

outcomes.response: Henriksson. But he's following orders. The production targets went up 15% last quarter. Safety budget got raided to fund overtime. They're literally spending the light money on keeping the furnace hot. And the county safety inspector? Bergström plays golf with him. Last inspection was a phone call.
outcomes.feedback: Systemic — production over safety, inspector corruption. Major story.
outcomes.note: Safety budget raided for production, inspector compromised

pressure.q1_note: Filed report, reference 74-382

silence.q1_response: ... You're just going to stand there? Fine. I'll tell you anyway. Krister Holm fell two meters in the dark on Tuesday. Cracked ribs. Nobody cares.
silence.expression_hint: Searching your face, then looking away

q2_options.text: Tell me about Krister.
You said nobody cares. Who specifically should care?

outcomes.response: Good man. Twenty years at the mill. Slipped on the grating because you can't see your own feet in sections C and D. Foreman blamed him.
outcomes.feedback: Human story but thin on evidence.
outcomes.note: Twenty-year veteran, foreman blamed him

outcomes.response: Krister's at home now. Wife says he can barely breathe. Doctor documented cracked ribs. But the company won't file an injury report because then the safety statistics look bad before the county review.
outcomes.feedback: Connected the cover-up to the county review — motive established.
outcomes.note: Injury suppressed before county safety review

outcomes.response: It's not just Krister. Nils Forsberg fell in September. Same spot. Same darkness. His report was filed — and then it vanished. I started keeping copies after that. I have three months of maintenance requests that went nowhere. All stamped 'non-critical' by Henriksson.
outcomes.feedback: Pattern of vanishing reports plus copies of evidence. He's been building a file.
outcomes.note: Multiple vanishing reports, worker keeping copies

silence.q1_note: Krister Holm fell, nobody cares

headlines.text: Night Shift Workers Report Safety Light Failures
Worker Falls in Darkened Mill — Company Blocks Injury Report
SAFETY BUDGET RAIDED: Mill Spent Light Money on Production

title: The Union Dues
description: A union member questions where the local chapter's fees are actually going.
lead_text: Fifty kronor a month. Four hundred members. That's a lot of money with nothing to show for it.
preview: An anonymous letter left at the newspaper office, handwritten on lined paper.

interview.opening_line: I wrote to you because I've tried everything else. The local chapter won't answer my questions about the money.

q1_options.text: That's frustrating, Maj-Britt. What questions are they refusing to answer?
How much are we talking about? Where should the money be going?
Is the chapter chairman stealing from the members?

friendly.q1_response: The solidarity fund. Every member pays fifty kronor a month. Four hundred members. That's twenty thousand a month, two hundred forty thousand a year. Where does it go? I asked at the last meeting. Göransson told me to 'trust the process.'
friendly.expression_hint: Leaning forward, hands on the table

q2_options.text: Have you seen any financial statements or annual reports from the chapter?
What should the solidarity fund be paying for?
How did other members react when you asked?

outcomes.response: No financial statements. They say they file them with the regional office. I called the regional office — they said the local chapter handles its own reporting. Everyone points somewhere else.
outcomes.feedback: Classic runaround but no concrete evidence of misuse.
outcomes.note: No financial statements available, circular accountability

outcomes.response: The fund is supposed to cover strike support, legal aid, and member education. But there hasn't been a training session in two years. No strike fund has been paid out. And Göransson just bought a summer cottage on Öland. On a shop floor salary.
outcomes.feedback: The chairman's new property versus frozen fund activities. Circumstantial but newsworthy.
outcomes.note: No fund activity in 2 years, chairman bought summer cottage

outcomes.response: I got a look at the bank statements. A friend at Handelsbanken. There are regular withdrawals — cash — by Göransson himself. Three, four thousand at a time. And the 'conference expenses' line? The last three conferences were at a resort hotel. Göransson went alone.
outcomes.feedback: Bank records showing cash withdrawals plus fake conference expenses. Documentary proof.
outcomes.note: Cash withdrawals by chairman, fake conference expenses

friendly.q1_note: 240,000 kr/year, no accounting

direct.q1_response: Two hundred forty thousand kronor a year. Fifty per member, four hundred members. It's supposed to go to the solidarity fund — strike support, legal aid, training. Nothing's been spent on any of that since '72.
direct.expression_hint: Counting on fingers with precision

q2_options.text: That's almost half a million in two years with no spending. Where's the money sitting?
Who controls the fund? Is there a board or just one person?
Have you requested an audit from the regional office?

outcomes.response: Göransson controls it. He's chairman, treasurer, and signatory. Nobody else has access. I asked for an audit and was told 'the books are in order.'
outcomes.feedback: One-man control with no oversight. Structural problem confirmed.
outcomes.note: Göransson sole controller, no audit allowed

outcomes.response: I requested an audit. Göransson said the regional office handles it. The regional office said they don't audit local funds. So I went to Handelsbanken myself. The account balance doesn't match what it should be. It's about 180,000 kronor short.
outcomes.feedback: 180,000 kronor gap in the fund. That's embezzlement territory.
outcomes.note: 180,000 kr missing from solidarity fund

outcomes.response: Here's what I found — the account balance is 58,000 kronor. After two years of collecting 240,000 annually with zero legitimate expenses, it should be close to half a million. And the withdrawals are all in Göransson's name. Cash. No receipts filed.
outcomes.feedback: Documented gap of ~400,000 kr with cash withdrawals traced to one person. Iron-clad.
outcomes.note: 58,000 in account vs ~480,000 expected, all cash withdrawals by Göransson

direct.q1_note: 240,000/year, nothing spent since '72

pressure.q1_response: Stealing? That's... I mean, I don't want to say that. But something is very wrong. The numbers don't add up. And Göransson gets very angry when anyone asks.

q2_options.text: I understand the hesitation. What specifically doesn't add up?
What happens when someone asks? Has anyone been retaliated against?
Göransson's anger — is it because the answer would be damaging?

outcomes.response: Four hundred members paying fifty kronor. No workshops, no strike fund payouts, no legal aid. The money goes in. Nothing comes out. That's what doesn't add up.
outcomes.feedback: The math problem is clear but she pulled back from the accusation.
outcomes.note: Money flows in, nothing visible comes out

outcomes.response: Lena Forsberg asked at the September meeting. Next week, her shift was changed to nights. Her husband works days. Now they never see each other. Göransson didn't say it was punishment. He didn't have to.
outcomes.feedback: Retaliation against a questioner. The fear is part of the story.
outcomes.note: Member's shift changed after questioning finances

outcomes.response: Two people have asked. Both got their shifts changed. And I heard from someone at Handelsbanken — the account is nearly empty. Almost half a million should be in there. It's not. You do the math.
outcomes.feedback: Retaliation pattern plus a near-empty account. The union is being robbed.
outcomes.note: Account nearly empty, two questioners retaliated against

pressure.q1_note: Something very wrong with the money

silence.q1_response: ... I know what you're thinking. Why would a union member go to the press? Because the union won't listen. My own union.
silence.expression_hint: Voice cracking slightly

q2_options.text: That must feel like a betrayal.
What did you try before coming here?

outcomes.response: I wrote to the regional office. They said to take it up at the local meeting. I did. Göransson told me I was 'undermining solidarity.' The irony, right?
outcomes.feedback: She's been stonewalled but only has the runaround story.
outcomes.note: Regional office deflected, chairman called her disloyal

outcomes.response: I asked at meetings. I wrote to the region. I even tried to look at the books. Göransson keeps them in a locked drawer in his office. But his neighbor told me about the summer cottage. And the boat. On a paper mill worker's salary.
outcomes.feedback: Lifestyle doesn't match income. The circumstantial case builds.
outcomes.note: Chairman has summer cottage and boat on factory salary

outcomes.response: I went to everyone. Nobody wanted to hear it. So I started keeping records myself. Every month's dues, every member's payment. Compare that to the bank balance — a friend checked for me. Almost 400,000 kronor has vanished. I have it all written down.
outcomes.feedback: She built her own audit. Hand-written evidence of 400,000 kr missing.
outcomes.note: Self-conducted audit shows ~400,000 kr missing, documented

silence.q1_note: Union won't listen, went to the press

headlines.text: Union Members Question Solidarity Fund Spending
240,000 Kronor a Year — No Accounting, No Answers
UNION BOSS'S COTTAGE: Where Did the Dues Go?

title: The Schoolyard
description: Parents near the Ståhlberg steel mill worry about dust settling on the school playground.
lead_text: My daughter comes home with grey dust in her hair every day. The school is 200 meters from the slag heap.
preview: A concerned woman approaches you outside the school gates, holding a child's hand.

interview.opening_line: Look at her hair. See the grey? That's not dirt. That's from the factory. And they play outside every day.

q1_options.text: That's alarming, Astrid. How long has this been going on?
Is it metal dust? Has anyone tested it?
Are the children getting sick? Is the school covering it up?

friendly.q1_response: Since they expanded the slag heap in the spring. The wind carries it right over. Little Maja coughs every night now. And she's not the only one — half the kids in her class have the same cough.
friendly.expression_hint: Stroking her daughter's hair protectively

q2_options.text: Have other parents complained? What does the school say?
Has a doctor looked at the coughing children?
How close is the slag heap to the playground exactly?

outcomes.response: The school says it's autumn colds. Normal, they say. But it's not normal. It started when the slag heap got bigger. We all see it.
outcomes.feedback: Concerned parent testimony but no medical or environmental evidence.
outcomes.note: School dismisses coughing as autumn colds

outcomes.response: Dr. Lindqvist at the health center has seen seven children this month with 'respiratory irritation.' Same class, same school. She won't say it's the dust on the record, but she told me privately it's not normal.
outcomes.feedback: Doctor sees the pattern. Off-the-record medical opinion strengthens the case.
outcomes.note: 7 children with respiratory issues, Dr. Lindqvist sees pattern

outcomes.response: I collected dust from the playground in a jar. Brought it to the pharmacy — the pharmacist said it looks like it contains heavy metals. And the headmaster? He got a letter from Ståhlbergs last month asking him not to 'alarm parents unnecessarily.' I saw a copy.
outcomes.feedback: Physical evidence plus corporate pressure on the school. The company knew.
outcomes.note: Dust contains heavy metals, Ståhlbergs pressured headmaster to stay quiet

friendly.q1_note: Slag heap expanded, children coughing

direct.q1_response: Nobody's tested it. That's the problem. The slag heap is 200 meters from the school. The wind blows from the west — straight over the playground — about three days a week. And the dust settles on everything.
direct.expression_hint: Pointing toward the factory stack visible above rooftops

q2_options.text: Has the school or the municipality measured air quality?
What's in a slag heap? Could it be toxic?
Who owns the land between the school and the factory?

outcomes.response: No measurements. The municipality says the factory has all required permits. End of discussion, as far as they're concerned.
outcomes.feedback: Municipality hiding behind permits. Bureaucratic deflection.
outcomes.note: Municipality says factory has permits, no measurements done

outcomes.response: The municipality hasn't measured anything. But I found out the school was built in 1962 — before the slag heap existed. The heap started in '68, expanded in '73. No environmental review was done when they expanded it. I checked.
outcomes.feedback: The school came first. No review when slag heap expanded. Procedural failure.
outcomes.note: No environmental review when slag heap expanded near school

outcomes.response: No review was done. And here's why — the land between the school and the slag heap belongs to Ståhlbergs. They donated it to the municipality in '61 to build the school. Then they built the slag heap 200 meters away. The municipality can't complain about their biggest taxpayer.
outcomes.feedback: The school is on company land. The municipality is trapped. Structural corruption.
outcomes.note: School on donated Ståhlbergs land, municipality can't challenge them

direct.q1_note: Slag heap 200m from school, no testing

pressure.q1_response: Sick? My Maja coughs every night. But covering it up? The school isn't evil — they're scared. Ståhlbergs employs half the parents. Nobody wants to make a fuss.
pressure.expression_hint: Lowering her voice, glancing at other parents

q2_options.text: What are the parents afraid of specifically?
Has the school been told not to raise concerns?
If the factory employs the parents, who protects the children?

outcomes.response: Afraid of rocking the boat. My husband works at the mill. If I make noise, what happens to his job? That's what everyone thinks.
outcomes.feedback: The fear is real but it's just a parent's worry, not evidence.
outcomes.note: Parents afraid for jobs at the mill

outcomes.response: The headmaster got a call from Bergström's office. 'Don't create unnecessary alarm.' I know because I was in the office when it happened. The headmaster went white.
outcomes.feedback: Direct corporate pressure on a public school. That's the story.
outcomes.note: Bergström's office called headmaster: 'don't create alarm'

outcomes.response: Bergström's office called the headmaster AND the health center. 'Don't create alarm.' Dr. Lindqvist was told not to link the children's symptoms to the factory. I know because she told me — off the record. She's terrified too. Everyone is.
outcomes.feedback: Coordinated suppression of both school and medical professionals. Explosive.
outcomes.note: Company pressured both school and health center to suppress concerns

pressure.q1_note: Children coughing, parents afraid to complain

silence.q1_response: ... You see that grey on the climbing frame? That's not paint. Touch it. Feel it. My daughter plays on that every day.
silence.expression_hint: Walking to the fence, scraping dust with her finger

q2_options.text: How many children play here every day?
Has anyone tried to get the dust analyzed?

outcomes.response: Eighty-five children. Kindergarten through sixth grade. They eat lunch and then they go outside. Into this. Every. Single. Day.
outcomes.feedback: The scale is clear but you need more than a worried parent.
outcomes.note: 85 children exposed daily

outcomes.response: I scraped some into a jar. Brought it to Ekström at the pharmacy. He said it's not ordinary dust — it's metallic. Could contain chromium, iron oxide, maybe worse. But he can't do a proper analysis. You'd need a lab.
outcomes.feedback: Pharmacist confirms metallic content. A lab test away from proof.
outcomes.note: Pharmacist says metallic dust, possible chromium

outcomes.response: I kept a jar of it. Ekström at the pharmacy says it's metallic. And last week I found something else — a letter in the school office waste bin. From Ståhlbergs to the headmaster. 'We appreciate your discretion regarding the expansion. The dust levels are within our internal targets.' They knew. They knew and they said nothing.
outcomes.feedback: Company letter acknowledging dust and requesting silence. This is the smoking gun.
outcomes.note: Company letter: 'We appreciate your discretion, dust within our targets'

silence.q1_note: Grey dust on the climbing frame

headlines.text: Parents Concerned About Dust Near Bruksskolan
Children Cough as Factory Dust Coats Playground
SILENCED: Mill Told School to Hide Dust Danger

title: The Mill Water
description: A retired worker says the factory's been dumping waste in the river since the sixties.
lead_text: The fish died ten years ago. We used to swim there as boys. Now it smells like chemicals.
preview: A wheezing old man at the local café insists on buying you coffee.

interview.opening_line: I worked there thirty-two years. I've seen what they put in the river. Sit down — I'll tell you everything.

q1_options.text: Thirty-two years — you must have seen a lot, Gösta. I'm listening.
What specific substances are they dumping? When did it start?
If you knew they were poisoning the river, why didn't you say something sooner?

friendly.q1_response: Started in '62 when they built the new acid bath. The runoff goes straight into Svartån. No treatment, no filter. Just a pipe into the river. Everyone knew.
friendly.expression_hint: Settling into his chair, glad someone's finally listening

q2_options.text: What kind of acid? Is the pipe still there?
When you say 'everyone knew' — does that include management?
Have you noticed any health effects in the people living near the river?

outcomes.response: Hydrochloric acid from the pickling process. The pipe's behind the loading dock — you can see it from the bridge if you know where to look. It runs at night, mostly.
outcomes.feedback: The pipe exists and you know where it is. A good start.
outcomes.note: Hydrochloric acid pipe behind loading dock, runs at night

outcomes.response: Hydrochloric acid, chromium rinse, and the cooling water from the furnace. The pipe runs into the river at night. And management knows — I was there when Bergström's father ordered it installed. 'Cheaper than treatment,' he said. I remember because my foreman laughed.
outcomes.feedback: Three pollutants, a management order, and a direct quote. Strong sourcing.
outcomes.note: Three pollutants, Bergström Sr ordered pipe: 'cheaper than treatment'

outcomes.response: In '71, the county did a water test downstream. The results were bad — heavy metals, pH levels way off. Bergström sent his lawyer to meet with the county inspector. After that meeting, the report was 'revised.' The final version said 'within acceptable parameters.' I know because the original inspector quit over it. He's still alive. Name's Holmgren.
outcomes.feedback: Falsified county report plus a named whistleblower. Massive story.
outcomes.note: 1971 water report falsified after Bergström's lawyer intervened, inspector Holmgren quit

friendly.q1_note: Acid runoff into Svartån since '62

direct.q1_response: Hydrochloric acid from the pickling line. Chromium from the plating wash. And whatever comes out of the cooling system — metals, oils, who knows what. Since 1962, through a 15-centimeter pipe into Svartån.
direct.expression_hint: Drawing a map on a napkin

q2_options.text: Is the pipe still active? Does anyone regulate it?
Have there been any official inspections of the discharge?
What volume are we talking about? How much goes in daily?

outcomes.response: Still active. They run it at night. The county is supposed to inspect annually but I haven't seen an inspector at that pipe in years. They inspect the front gate — not the back.
outcomes.feedback: Pipe is active, inspections are superficial. But it's his word.
outcomes.note: Pipe active, night discharge, inspections miss it

outcomes.response: Still pumping every night. About 2,000 liters goes through between midnight and four AM. The county inspected in '71 — found violations. Then Bergström's lawyer showed up and the report was 'adjusted.' The violations disappeared from the final version.
outcomes.feedback: Volume estimate plus a falsified inspection report. Documentary angle.
outcomes.note: 2,000 liters nightly, 1971 inspection report falsified

outcomes.response: Two thousand liters a night, twelve years straight. Do the math — that's almost nine million liters of contaminated water. In '71 the county found violations and Bergström had the report changed. The inspector who filed it — Stig Holmgren — was pressured to resign. He lives in Karlstad now. I have his address if you want to talk to him.
outcomes.feedback: Nine million liters, falsified report, and a named witness. This could bring the factory down.
outcomes.note: 9 million liters over 12 years, fired inspector in Karlstad

direct.q1_note: HCl, chromium, oils — 15cm pipe into Svartån

pressure.q1_response: Why didn't I? Because I had a family to feed! You try being a whistleblower when the factory is the only employer in town. I waited until I retired. Are you going to listen or judge?

q2_options.text: You're right. I'm sorry. Tell me what you saw.
You're safe now though. What exactly did they dump?
Other workers must have seen it too. Who else knows?

outcomes.response: Acid and metal wash. Through a pipe into the river. Everyone on the night shift knew. We just... didn't talk about it.
outcomes.feedback: Basic facts confirmed but he's holding back after the aggressive start.
outcomes.note: Night shift knew about the dumping

outcomes.response: Fine. Hydrochloric acid and chromium waste. A pipe behind the dock. Two thousand liters a night. I know because I maintained the pump for seven years. And every time there was an inspection, we'd shut it off the day before. Someone always tipped us off.
outcomes.feedback: Inside knowledge of the concealment system. He maintained the pump.
outcomes.note: Pump shut off before inspections, someone tipped them off

outcomes.response: I maintained that pump for seven years. I know exactly what went through it. And I kept a logbook — dates, volumes, what they ran. My own record, hidden at home. Because I knew this day would come. I also know the inspector who tried to report it and was forced out. Holmgren. He'll talk.
outcomes.feedback: Seven years of personal logbooks plus a willing second source. Explosive investigative material.
outcomes.note: Personal logbook of 7 years of dumping data, plus second source

pressure.q1_note: Waited until retirement to speak

silence.q1_response: ... Smart. You wait. Like I waited. Thirty-two years I waited. The river turned grey. The fish died. My grandchildren can't swim where I swam. And the factory keeps pumping.
silence.expression_hint: Staring at his coffee, then at the window toward the river

q2_options.text: The river turned grey.
What changed that made you want to talk now?

outcomes.response: Grey and sometimes green. Depends on what they're running. The acid turns it grey. The chromium gives it a shimmer. You can still see it from the bridge on a moonlit night.
outcomes.feedback: Vivid description but it's an old man's memory. You need more.
outcomes.note: Grey and green river, visible from the bridge

outcomes.response: My grandson asked me why the river smells. I couldn't lie to him. So I'll tell you instead. Two thousand liters a night. Acid and metals. And the county knew — they tested it in '71. The results disappeared.
outcomes.feedback: The grandson triggered it. Emotional and factual — the disappeared results give it weight.
outcomes.note: 2,000 liters nightly, 1971 test results disappeared

outcomes.response: I'm dying. Doctor says the lungs. Thirty-two years of breathing what they put in the water and the air. I kept a logbook. Seven years of dates and volumes. And I know who else can confirm it — Stig Holmgren, the county inspector they pushed out. Here. Take this.
outcomes.feedback: A dying man's logbook and a second source. This is the biggest environmental story in the county.
outcomes.note: Terminally ill, 7-year logbook, corroborating witness Holmgren

silence.q1_note: Waited thirty-two years to speak

headlines.text: Retired Worker Claims Mill Dumps Acid in River
Thirty-Two Years of Poison: Inside the Mill's Hidden Pipe
NINE MILLION LITERS: The Pipe Ståhlbergs Doesn't Want You to See

title: The Wage Slip
description: A leaked document shows management planned to reject the wage increase before negotiations even started.
lead_text: They had the answer ready before we even sat down. The whole negotiation was a show.
preview: An envelope slipped under the office door overnight, containing a photocopied memo.

interview.opening_line: I typed that memo. I know what it says. They decided the outcome before the union even entered the room.

q1_options.text: That took courage, Kerstin. What exactly did the memo say?
When was the memo dated? Who wrote it and who received it?
This looks like bad-faith bargaining. Is that what you're saying?

friendly.q1_response: Two weeks before the wage negotiations. Director Bergström to the board: 'The request will be denied regardless of presentation. Prepare conciliatory language for the press release.' They had the press release written before the meeting.
friendly.expression_hint: Speaking quietly, checking the door

q2_options.text: A press release already written? Can you describe it?
What was the union asking for? Was it unreasonable?
Were there other memos like this? Is it a pattern?

outcomes.response: The press release said management had 'carefully considered the proposal' and found it 'incompatible with current market conditions.' Word for word what they said after the meeting. They didn't consider anything.
outcomes.feedback: Pre-written rejection language. Embarrassing but not illegal.
outcomes.note: Press release drafted before negotiations — identical language used

outcomes.response: The union asked for a 4% raise. Industry standard. The memo said: 'Offer 1.5% with improved canteen facilities as compromise. Cost of canteen improvements: negligible. Optics: positive.' They planned the whole kabuki.
outcomes.feedback: Scripted negotiation with calculated optics. Shows contempt for the process.
outcomes.note: 4% requested, pre-planned 1.5% offer, canteen 'improvement' as cover

outcomes.response: The memo included a line I'll never forget: 'Union leadership will accept 1.5% — Göransson has been briefed and will recommend acceptance.' The union chairman was in on it. They fixed the negotiation from both sides.
outcomes.feedback: Collusion between management and union leadership. Both sides betrayed the workers.
outcomes.note: Union chairman Göransson pre-briefed, agreed to accept 1.5%

friendly.q1_note: Memo: rejection decided before negotiation

direct.q1_response: October 14th. From Bergström to the board — Lundgren, Ståhl, and Franzén. CC'd to the company lawyer. Marked 'strictly confidential.' I have the carbon copy.
direct.expression_hint: Tapping a plain brown envelope on the table

q2_options.text: Can I see the carbon copy?
What specifically does the memo instruct the board to do?
Why was the company lawyer CC'd?

outcomes.response: The memo says to reject any increase above 1.5%. The rest is strategy language — 'maintain firm position,' 'express sympathy for worker concerns.' Standard manipulation.
outcomes.feedback: Clear rejection strategy but could be defended as normal negotiation prep.
outcomes.note: Reject above 1.5%, 'express sympathy' strategy

outcomes.response: Here — read it yourself. 'Reject any increase above 1.5%. If union threatens action, remind them of the oil crisis and potential layoffs. Layoffs are not planned but the threat is useful.' They weaponized job insecurity.
outcomes.feedback: Written admission of using false layoff threats as leverage. This is the story.
outcomes.note: Memo admits fake layoff threats as negotiation weapon

title: The Fire Drill
description: A fire drill at the paper mill revealed emergency exits blocked by stored materials.
lead_text: We couldn't get out. Three exits, all blocked. The fire chief was furious.
preview: A mill worker approaches you outside the library, looking over his shoulder.

interview.opening_line: Last Thursday's fire drill. It was a disaster. But nobody's talking about it because the company 'resolved it internally.'

q1_options.text: That sounds serious, Rune. Tell me what happened during the drill.
Which exits were blocked? What was blocking them?
If there had been a real fire, how many people would have died?

friendly.q1_response: Fire bell rings at 14:00. My section — forty-three men — start moving to the exits. Exit B: pallets of raw paper stacked floor to ceiling. Exit C: a forklift parked across the door. Exit D: chained shut. We had to go all the way back to the main entrance.
friendly.expression_hint: Counting exits on his fingers, getting agitated

q2_options.text: What did the fire chief say when he saw this?
How long did it take everyone to get out?
Who authorized storing materials in front of the exits?

outcomes.response: Twelve minutes for full evacuation. Standard should be under four. The fire chief told the production manager it was 'unacceptable.' Next day, the pallets were moved. Problem solved, they said.
outcomes.feedback: Three times the evacuation standard. Quick fix but no accountability.
outcomes.note: 12-minute evacuation vs 4-minute standard

outcomes.response: Fire chief Bengtsson was livid. He wrote a formal violation report. I saw him hand it to the production manager. But here's the thing — when I asked about it this week, the production manager said 'no formal report was filed.' It vanished.
outcomes.feedback: Disappeared violation report. The cover-up is the story.
outcomes.note: Fire chief's violation report disappeared

outcomes.response: Bengtsson filed a violation report. It disappeared. But what they don't know is that I was there when he filed it, and I wrote down the reference number — FV-74-019. You can call the fire department and ask for it. If it's not in their files either, then someone in the municipality is covering for the factory.
outcomes.feedback: Reference number you can verify independently. If it's missing from fire department records too, it's a conspiracy.
outcomes.note: Violation report FV-74-019 — verifiable, may have been purged from fire dept too

friendly.q1_note: Three exits blocked, 43 men trapped

direct.q1_response: Exit B: raw paper pallets, about three meters high. Exit C: forklift parked sideways, keys removed. Exit D: padlocked. A padlock on a fire exit. The fire code is very clear about that.
direct.expression_hint: Speaking precisely, a supervisor's attention to detail

q2_options.text: Who has the key to Exit D? Why was it locked?
Does the fire department know about this? Was it reported?
Is the fire code violation still ongoing, or did they fix it?

outcomes.response: They moved the pallets and the forklift the next day. Exit D was unlocked. The production manager called it a 'temporary storage solution' that 'unfortunately coincided with the drill.'
outcomes.feedback: Quick fix with corporate language. No accountability trail.
outcomes.note: Fixed after drill, called 'temporary storage solution'

outcomes.response: Exit D was locked because of theft. Someone was stealing paper stock. Instead of hiring a guard, they chained the exit. The fire chief filed a violation — number FV-74-019. When I checked this week, the production manager denied any report was filed.
outcomes.feedback: Locked exit to prevent theft, disappeared violation report.
outcomes.note: Exit locked to prevent theft, violation FV-74-019 denied

outcomes.response: I checked all four sections this morning. Exit D is unlocked now — but Exit B has pallets again. Already. One week later. And the violation report? Gone from both the factory and the fire department records. Someone made it disappear. I took a photo of the exits with my own camera. Want to see?
outcomes.feedback: Exits re-blocked already, violation report erased from two agencies, photographic evidence.
outcomes.note: Exits re-blocked after one week, report erased, worker has photos

direct.q1_note: Exit B: pallets, C: forklift, D: padlocked

pressure.q1_response: Dead? In a real fire? All forty-three of us in section four. Maybe more. You can do the math — three exits blocked, one entrance, twelve minutes to evacuate.

q2_options.text: Has anyone done the math officially? What do fire safety standards say?
Are the exits still blocked right now?
If this is as dangerous as you say, why hasn't the fire department shut the mill down?

outcomes.response: Standards say under four minutes for full evacuation. We took twelve. The fire department can order a shutdown but they need to file a violation report first. And that report seems to have disappeared.
outcomes.feedback: The gap between standard and reality, plus the missing report.
outcomes.note: 4-min standard vs 12-min actual, report missing

outcomes.response: The fire department should have shut us down. Fire chief Bengtsson wanted to. But his report — FV-74-019 — never made it into the system. I asked at the fire station yesterday. They have no record of it. Bengtsson is on leave. 'Personal reasons.'
outcomes.feedback: Missing report, fire chief on sudden leave. Looks like suppression.
outcomes.note: Fire chief Bengtsson on sudden leave, report vanished from system

outcomes.response: Because someone killed the report. And Bengtsson — who filed it — was told to take leave. 'Stress,' they said. But I talked to him at home. He says his supervisor was called by someone at the municipality. And I have photos of the exits — taken two days ago. They're already blocked again.
outcomes.feedback: Municipal-level cover-up, intimidated fire chief, photographic proof of ongoing violation.
outcomes.note: Municipality called fire chief's boss, exits re-blocked, photos exist

pressure.q1_note: Forty-three men would have died

silence.q1_response: ... Forty-three men in my section. One working exit. Paper everywhere — a paper mill, for God's sake. The most flammable workplace in Sweden, and they block the fire exits.
silence.expression_hint: Shaking his head slowly, gripping the edge of the table

q2_options.text: A paper mill with blocked fire exits.
You're a supervisor. What would you do if it caught fire?

outcomes.response: I'd try to get my men to the main entrance. A hundred meters through the production floor. Past the drying ovens. With burning paper falling from the ceiling. You see the problem.
outcomes.feedback: Vivid horror scenario but only his assessment.
outcomes.note: Only escape route passes drying ovens and burning paper

outcomes.response: I've thought about it every night this week. And then I thought — there's a fire drill record. The fire chief filed a violation. But the company says it was never filed. So I went to the fire station myself. They have no record either. Someone erased it.
outcomes.feedback: Records erased from both factory and fire department. Concerted cover-up.
outcomes.note: Violation erased from both factory and fire department records

outcomes.response: I'd watch my men die. That's the truth. And the worst part? They 'fixed' the exits after the drill. I checked yesterday — Exit B is blocked again. With paper. In a paper mill. And the fire chief who reported it is on 'sick leave.' I'm done being quiet. Here — I brought photos.
outcomes.feedback: Re-blocked exit one week later, intimidated fire chief, photographic evidence. Front page.
outcomes.note: Exit re-blocked in one week, fire chief forced on leave, photos taken

silence.q1_note: Most flammable workplace, exits blocked
