q2_options.text: Has anyone challenged the company legally on this?
Is there a pension fund board? Who oversees it?
Can I photograph these documents?

outcomes.response: Legal challenge? With what money? We live on the pension. Or what's left of it. The union said they'd 'look into it.' That was in October. Nothing since.
outcomes.feedback: Contractual violation clear but no legal action underway. Union passive.
outcomes.note: Union said they'd 'look into it' in October — nothing since

outcomes.response: The pension fund board has three members. Two are company-appointed: the CFO and the plant director. The third is supposed to be a worker representative — but it's the former union chairman, Arne Grip. Arne retired in '70 on a full pension. His pension wasn't cut. That tells you everything.
outcomes.feedback: The pension board is stacked with company men. And the one 'worker representative' got his full pension — while others were cut.
outcomes.note: Pension board: 2 company execs + 1 ex-union chair whose pension wasn't cut

outcomes.response: Photograph them. Here's something else — my son-in-law got the pension fund's annual report through the corporate registry. In 1972, the fund held 14.2 million kronor. In 1973, it was 8.1 million. The annual report lists 'investment in company operations' of 6 million. They used our pension money to buy the new rolling mill. Our retirement funded their expansion. And the auditor? The auditor signed off on it. Same auditing firm that handles the company's books.
outcomes.feedback: Pension fund raided for 6 million to buy equipment. Auditor conflict of interest. The retirees financed the very expansion that makes the owners richer while their pensions shrink.
outcomes.note: 6M pension fund used for rolling mill. Same auditor for company and pension fund.

direct.q1_note: Contract says 'not subject to reduction'

pressure.q1_response: Of course it's breach of contract. But who's going to enforce it? The company has lawyers. We have a rusty coffee pot and each other. You want to know how scared we are? Last week Evert refused to accept the reduced check. They told him he could 'take it or leave it.' Leave thirty-eight years of earned pension.
pressure.expression_hint: Coughing, then speaking with quiet fury

q2_options.text: How much is the total impact across all retirees? What's the scale?
Would the retirees be willing to be named in print?
What happened to the money that was in the fund?

outcomes.response: There must be two hundred of us drawing from that fund. If everyone lost 30%, that's... a lot of money that went somewhere. But where? Nobody tells us.
outcomes.feedback: Scale is significant — 200 retirees — but no specifics on where the money went.
outcomes.note: ~200 retirees affected by cuts, money destination unknown

outcomes.response: Eight of us will talk. We met at Evert's kitchen last week. He's the bravest — he served in the merchant navy during the war, not afraid of the company. And Signe, widow of a mill worker, she'll talk. Her husband died on the job in '68 and she depends entirely on the survivor's pension. That was cut too.
outcomes.feedback: Group of named sources including a war veteran and a worker's widow. Human faces for the story.
outcomes.note: 8 retirees willing to be named — includes war veteran and worker's widow on survivor's pension

outcomes.response: One of the pensioners — I won't say who — used to be the fund administrator before he retired. He told me the board approved a 'temporary reallocation' of fund assets in February '73. The minutes say temporary. There's no repayment schedule. No interest. And the fund's bylaws require a two-thirds majority to change pension terms — the vote was 2-1. The worker representative voted against but was overruled. They broke their own rules.
outcomes.feedback: 'Temporary' reallocation with no repayment, approved by a 2-1 vote when bylaws require two-thirds. They violated their own governance to raid the fund.
outcomes.note: Bylaws require 2/3 majority — vote was 2-1. Worker rep voted against. No repayment schedule.

pressure.q1_note: Evert told 'take it or leave it'

silence.q1_response: ...My wife cried when that check came. We already live on potatoes and herring most days. I promised her a good retirement. I worked for it. And now I sit here and I can't even... I can't even keep her warm.
silence.expression_hint: Voice breaking, wife puts hand on his shoulder

q2_options.text: What would a proper pension amount mean for your daily life?
Have other retirees reached out to each other?
Do you still have your original pension documents?

outcomes.response: Seven hundred kronor a month. That's what we lost. It's the heating bill. It's medicine. It's whether I can buy my grandchildren Christmas presents. Small things that make life worth living.
outcomes.feedback: The human cost is clear but you need more than one man's story. Get the documents.
outcomes.note: 700kr/month — difference between heating and cold, medicine and none

outcomes.response: We've started meeting at the church on Tuesdays. Last week, twenty-three showed up. Some of them brought their pension letters. All identical wording. Same date. Same cut. This was planned. Coordinated. They did this to all of us at once so no one could fight it alone.
outcomes.feedback: Twenty-three retirees organized. Identical letters prove a coordinated action. Group testimony.
outcomes.note: 23 retirees meeting at church — identical letters, coordinated cut

outcomes.response: I found something in my papers last night. From 1965, when they set up the pension fund. The founding document. It says — here, read it yourself — 'Fund assets shall not be used for purposes other than pension disbursement without unanimous consent of all beneficiaries.' Unanimous. They didn't ask a single one of us. Two lawyers and an accountant could turn this into a criminal case. Will you print that clause?
outcomes.feedback: The founding document requires unanimous consent for any non-pension use of fund assets. They had no consent at all. This is the legal bombshell.
outcomes.note: Founding document: 'unanimous consent of all beneficiaries' required — none were asked

silence.q1_note: Can't keep his wife warm anymore

headlines.text: Retired Workers Report Sudden Pension Cuts at Mill
Thirty-Eight Years at the Mill — Then a Pension Cut Without Warning
MILL RAIDED WORKERS' PENSION FUND TO FINANCE EXPANSION — RETIREES GO COLD

title: Poisoned Wells
description: Residents near the chemical plant report brown water and dead fish in the creek.
lead_text: Three families on Fabriksgatan have stopped drinking tap water. Their well water turned brown last month.
preview: A typed letter with a water test report arrives at the newsroom.

interview.opening_line: I've been a nurse for thirty-two years. I know what chemicals do to a body. And I know what I'm smelling in my water.

q1_options.text: You must be worried for your neighbors, Astrid. When did you first notice it?
Do you have the water test results? What chemicals were found?
The plant says their runoff is within legal limits. Are you saying they're lying?

friendly.q1_response: September. I noticed the tomatoes in my garden had black spots. Then the water started smelling like metal. Three of us on the street went to the pharmacy for test kits.
friendly.expression_hint: Pulling back a curtain to show the garden

q2_options.text: What did the pharmacy test kits show?
Have any of your neighbors gotten sick?
Did you contact the plant about it?

outcomes.response: The kits aren't very precise - just showed 'elevated metals.' But we can taste it. The children won't drink it anymore.
outcomes.feedback: Anecdotal evidence but no hard data. Needs more.
outcomes.note: Pharmacy kits showed 'elevated metals'

outcomes.response: My neighbor Greta, she's 74 - she's had stomach problems since October. And the Lindqvist children have rashes. I wrote it all down. Dates, symptoms, everything. Here.
outcomes.feedback: A documented health log from a trained nurse. Credible evidence.
outcomes.note: Nurse's log: stomach problems, rashes since October

outcomes.response: I sent a sample to the university lab in Gothenburg. Paid for it myself - 200 kronor. Hexavalent chromium. Four times the safe limit. The plant is the only possible source. I have the lab report right here.
outcomes.feedback: Independent lab results with specific chemical and levels. Devastating.
outcomes.note: Hexavalent chromium 4x safe limit - university lab report

friendly.q1_note: Black spots on tomatoes, metallic water since September

direct.q1_response: I paid for a proper analysis from Gothenburg University. Here. Hexavalent chromium at 0.21 milligrams per liter. The Swedish limit is 0.05. And cadmium traces.
direct.expression_hint: Placing a lab report on the table

q2_options.text: Has the municipality seen these results?
How many households are affected?
What's the plant's position on this?

outcomes.response: I sent a copy to the environmental office. They said they'd 'look into it.' That was six weeks ago. Nothing happened.
outcomes.feedback: Municipal inaction confirmed, but no documentation of the cover-up.
outcomes.note: Environmental office: 'look into it' — six weeks ago

outcomes.response: At least twelve houses on Fabriksgatan and Bruksgatan. I've been going door to door. Seven families are buying bottled water now. Out of their own pockets. The plant won't even acknowledge the complaint.
outcomes.feedback: Scale of the problem quantified. Multiple affected families documented.
outcomes.note: 12 houses, 7 families buying bottled water

outcomes.response: I got hold of the plant's own internal monitoring reports through a friend who works there. Their own numbers show the contamination. They've known since June. But the report was marked 'internal only - do not distribute.' Here's the copy.
outcomes.feedback: The plant's own data proves they knew. A cover-up with documentary evidence.
outcomes.note: Plant's own report shows contamination since June — marked 'do not distribute'

direct.q1_note: Chromium 0.21 mg/L — limit is 0.05

pressure.q1_response: Legal limits? They set their own monitoring schedule. They test when they want, where they want. I'm saying the system lets them poison us legally.
pressure.expression_hint: Voice rising, finger pointing at the factory chimneys

q2_options.text: But do you have proof the water is actually contaminated?
Who at the plant is responsible for environmental monitoring?
Are you saying the regulatory system itself is broken?

outcomes.response: Proof? Taste my water. Look at my garden. But no, I don't have a lab report with a stamp on it, if that's what you mean. Not yet.
outcomes.feedback: Emotional but no hard evidence. The anger is real but the story needs data.
outcomes.note: No lab confirmation yet

outcomes.response: Karl-Axel Bergström signs off on the monitoring reports himself. Environmental director AND production director. Same man. You see the problem? The fox guarding the henhouse.
outcomes.feedback: Clear conflict of interest at the top. Structural problem exposed.
outcomes.note: Bergström signs both production and environmental reports

outcomes.response: I found out through a source at the county office that the plant was supposed to install new filtration in 1972. They got a two-year extension. Then another. The money went to the new office building instead. And the county inspector? He's Bergström's brother-in-law.
outcomes.feedback: Corruption chain: skipped filtration, diverted funds, nepotistic oversight. Explosive.
outcomes.note: Filtration money → office building. Inspector is Bergström's brother-in-law

pressure.q1_note: Plant sets its own monitoring schedule

silence.q1_response: ...You're not the first reporter I've talked to. The last one from Fabriksbladet sat right there. Listened. Wrote nothing. I need to know you're different.
silence.expression_hint: Searching your face for sincerity

q2_options.text: I'm listening. Tell me what the other reporter didn't want to hear.
What happened when Fabriksbladet came?
What would it take for you to trust me with the full story?

outcomes.response: He said 'we'll run it next week.' That was in October. I called the office three times. Last time they said the story 'didn't meet editorial standards.' Someone got to them.
outcomes.feedback: Evidence of competitor suppressing the story, but no new facts about the contamination.
outcomes.note: Fabriksbladet killed the story after October visit

outcomes.response: I'll tell you what I told him AND what I found after. The plant dumps at night. Between 2 and 4 AM. I've been watching. I photographed the discharge pipe running full bore at 3 AM last Tuesday. Brown water straight into Bruksån.
outcomes.feedback: Photographic evidence of nighttime dumping. Major.
outcomes.note: Night dumping photographed at 3 AM — discharge into Bruksån

outcomes.response: After Fabriksbladet buried it, I started keeping a proper file. Dates, photos, the lab report, health records from seven families. And yesterday I got this — a resignation letter from the plant's former chemist. He quit because they told him to falsify the water quality data. His name is Stig Åberg. He's willing to talk. On the record.
outcomes.feedback: A complete investigative file plus a whistleblower willing to go on record. Front page.
outcomes.note: Former chemist quit over falsified data — willing to testify

silence.q1_note: Fabriksbladet already killed this story

headlines.text: Residents Report Discolored Water Near Chemical Plant
Lab Tests Reveal Contamination in Industristad Wells
POISON IN THE TAP — Chemical Plant Knew Since June

title: The Union Traitor
description: A union shop steward is secretly negotiating with management behind the membership's back.
lead_text: I saw Persson in Bergström's office after hours. Twice. Something's going on.
preview: An anonymous note slipped under the newsroom door, typed on a factory typewriter.

interview.opening_line: I've been in the union twenty years. I know what loyalty looks like. And I know what betrayal looks like. Persson is selling us out.

q1_options.text: Twenty years is a long time, Arne. What did you see that convinced you?
What specifically did you witness? Dates, times, who was present?
This is a serious accusation. Persson could sue. Are you prepared for that?

friendly.q1_response: I stayed late to fix a welding rig on a Thursday — October 17th. Saw Persson coming out of the executive corridor. He looked like he'd seen a ghost when he noticed me. Said he was 'checking something.' At ten at night.
friendly.expression_hint: Clenching and unclenching his fists

q2_options.text: Did you confront him about it?
Has Persson's behavior changed recently in union meetings?
Was anyone else with him?

outcomes.response: I asked him the next day. He laughed it off. Said I was seeing things. But I know what I saw. The man was sweating.
outcomes.feedback: One sighting, denied. His word against Persson's.
outcomes.note: Persson denied late-night visit to executive corridor

outcomes.response: In the last two meetings, he's been pushing for 'reasonable expectations' on the wage demand. Those are management's words. Last year he wanted 15%. Now suddenly 6% is 'realistic.' Something changed.
outcomes.feedback: Clear shift in negotiating position. Pattern of compromise.
outcomes.note: Wage demand dropped from 15% to 6% — using management language

outcomes.response: I talked to his wife at the market. She let slip they're buying a summer cottage. On a shop steward's salary? And last month Persson's son got a foreman position. The kid is 22 with no experience. You tell me that's a coincidence.
outcomes.feedback: Personal enrichment — cottage + son's promotion. Quid pro quo evidence.
outcomes.note: New cottage + son promoted to foreman at 22

friendly.q1_note: Persson seen in executive corridor at 10 PM, October 17th

direct.q1_response: October 17th, around 22:00. Executive corridor, third floor. Then again October 31st, same time. I wrote it down both times. Also who was still in the building — only Bergström's light was on upstairs.
direct.expression_hint: Pulling a small notebook from his breast pocket

q2_options.text: Do you know what they discussed?
Has anyone else noticed Persson's meetings?
What do you think management is getting from Persson?

outcomes.response: No. Closed doors. But I know this: the week after the first meeting, Persson suddenly dropped the overtime pay demand from negotiations. Just took it off the table. The members never voted on that.
outcomes.feedback: Correlation between meetings and concessions, but no direct proof of deal.
outcomes.note: Overtime demand dropped after first meeting — no member vote

outcomes.response: Mats in the paint shop saw it too. And there's a third meeting I didn't see but heard about — September. Before the contract talks even started. Persson already knew what he was going to give up.
outcomes.feedback: Multiple witnesses and a pattern of pre-negotiation meetings.
outcomes.note: Second witness: Mats. Third meeting in September before talks began

outcomes.response: I got hold of the draft contract Persson showed management. It's not the version the members voted on. Three clauses removed: overtime rates, safety committee veto, and the asbestos clause. He's negotiating with a version the members have never seen.
outcomes.feedback: Documentary proof — a secret contract with removed protections. The smoking gun.
outcomes.note: Secret contract draft: overtime, safety veto, and asbestos clause removed

direct.q1_note: Two meetings logged: Oct 17 and Oct 31, executive corridor

pressure.q1_response: Sue me? For what? For telling the truth? I've got 312 union brothers counting on honest representation. If Persson is making deals with management, they deserve to know.

q2_options.text: But what if there's an innocent explanation?
What are you prepared to do about it?
Is this personal between you and Persson?

outcomes.response: An innocent explanation for meeting the boss in secret at night? While negotiating our contract? I'm not stupid and neither are you.
outcomes.feedback: Strong conviction but still circumstantial. Needs documentation.
outcomes.note: Sundström insists: no innocent explanation for secret meetings

outcomes.response: This isn't personal. Three of us — me, Mats, and Gunvor — we've been tracking this for weeks. We filed a complaint with the regional union office. They said they'd investigate. That was a month ago. Nothing.
outcomes.feedback: Organized group complaint, regional union inaction. Institutional failure.
outcomes.note: Three workers filed complaint — regional union took no action

outcomes.response: I'll tell you what I'm prepared to do. I have a tape. Persson called me from the plant phone last week to 'discuss strategy.' I recorded it. He says, and I quote: 'Bergström promised the safety clause stays if we drop overtime. It's the best deal we'll get.' He's admitting it. On tape.
outcomes.feedback: Audio evidence of the deal. Persson in his own words admitting negotiation with Bergström.
outcomes.note: Tape recording: 'Bergström promised safety clause stays if we drop overtime'

pressure.q1_note: 312 union members relying on honest representation

silence.q1_response: ...Look. I didn't want to come here. I tried the union structure first. I tried talking to Persson. I even wrote to the national office. Nobody wants to touch this. You're my last option.
silence.expression_hint: Sitting heavily, suddenly looking tired

q2_options.text: What happened when you talked to Persson?
Why do you think nobody wants to investigate?
Take your time. What's the most important thing you need people to know?

outcomes.response: He told me to mind my own business. Said I was jealous because I didn't get the shop steward position. Maybe I am. But that doesn't make what he's doing right.
outcomes.feedback: Honest admission of possible bias. Credible but thin on evidence.
outcomes.note: Persson dismissed concerns — Arne admits possible jealousy

outcomes.response: Because Persson has connections everywhere. His brother is on the county council. His predecessor retired quietly with a management consultancy contract. This is how it works in Industristad. You play ball, you get taken care of.
outcomes.feedback: Pattern of institutional corruption — previous steward also compromised.
outcomes.note: Previous steward got management consultancy. Persson's brother on county council

outcomes.response: The most important thing? Forty-seven men in the steel section work with asbestos insulation daily. No masks, no protective suits. The safety clause in our contract was supposed to fix that. Persson traded it away. Men will die from this deal. That's what's at stake.
outcomes.feedback: Human cost crystallized — asbestos exposure traded away. Life-and-death stakes.
outcomes.note: 47 men exposed to asbestos daily — safety clause traded away

silence.q1_note: Exhausted every internal channel before coming to press

headlines.text: Union Questions Arise Over Contract Negotiations
Shop Steward Held Secret Meetings With Management
BETRAYED — Union Boss Cut Secret Deal on Worker Safety

title: The Invisible Injuries
description: Workers at the steel mill are reporting hearing loss and lung problems that aren't in official health records.
lead_text: My husband can't hear me anymore unless I shout. The company doctor says he's fine.
preview: A woman approaches you at the market, looking over her shoulder.

interview.opening_line: They'll say I'm a worried wife making a fuss. But I've talked to the other wives. It's not just my husband. It's all of them.

q1_options.text: It must be frightening watching your husband's health change. How many families have you spoken with?
How many workers are affected? What are the specific symptoms?
If the company doctor is lying, that's a criminal matter. Are you ready to make that claim?

friendly.q1_response: Fourteen wives that I know of. We started talking at the school pickup — our kids go to Bruksskolan. One by one, the same story. Hearing problems. Coughing that won't stop. Headaches.
friendly.expression_hint: Counting on her fingers, each name a weight

q2_options.text: Has anyone tried to get a second medical opinion?
Have you noticed when the symptoms started getting worse?
What does the company doctor actually say when they go in?

outcomes.response: The company doctor — Dr. Holm — he does the checkups. Same thing every time: 'within normal range.' But my husband can't hear the phone ring anymore. That's not normal.
outcomes.feedback: Pattern of dismissal by company doctor, but no counter-evidence yet.
outcomes.note: Dr. Holm: 'within normal range' despite hearing loss

outcomes.response: Three of us went to Dr. Ekblad in town — paid out of pocket. He diagnosed Sven with 40% hearing loss in both ears and early-stage COPD. The company record says 'healthy.' I have both reports. They don't match.
outcomes.feedback: Two conflicting medical records. Company doctor clearly understating damage.
outcomes.note: Independent doctor: 40% hearing loss, COPD. Company record says 'healthy'

outcomes.response: Agnes Forsberg's husband died last year. Lung cancer. The company doctor had cleared him three months before. I got hold of his actual company health file through Agnes — it had notes that were crossed out. Someone altered his records. Agnes has the originals her husband kept secretly.
outcomes.feedback: Altered health records, death possibly related. Documentary evidence of cover-up.
outcomes.note: Dead worker's records altered — original copies exist showing crossed-out notes

friendly.q1_note: 14 families with same symptoms — hearing, coughing, headaches

direct.q1_response: I've counted at least fourteen in the steel section. Symptoms: progressive hearing loss, chronic cough, headaches, and three cases of what looks like nervous system damage — tremors, memory problems. All men under fifty.
direct.expression_hint: Reading from a small notebook

q2_options.text: What workplace conditions could cause all these symptoms together?
Are these workers all in the same department?
Has anyone filed an occupational injury report?

outcomes.response: Steel section and the alloy department. High noise, metal dust, and they started using a new chemical treatment for the steel two years ago. Nobody was told what was in it.
outcomes.feedback: Environmental factors identified but no specific chemical or proof of negligence.
outcomes.note: New chemical treatment introduced 2 years ago — composition unknown

outcomes.response: Sven filed an injury report last March. It was rejected by the company. The safety officer — who reports to management — ruled it 'age-related hearing loss.' Sven is 38. I have the rejection letter.
outcomes.feedback: Documented rejection of legitimate claim. Safety officer conflict of interest.
outcomes.note: Injury report rejected: '38-year-old diagnosed with age-related hearing loss'

outcomes.response: I've been building a file for six months. Fourteen cases documented. Independent medical exams for five of them. A chemical analysis of the dust in the ventilation — it contains manganese compounds well above safe levels. And the company's own safety manual says those filters should be changed monthly. They haven't been changed in over a year.
outcomes.feedback: Complete investigative file: cases, independent exams, dust analysis, maintenance neglect.
outcomes.note: Manganese dust above limits, filters unchanged for over a year, 14 documented cases

direct.q1_note: 14 workers, hearing loss, COPD symptoms, tremors

pressure.q1_response: Criminal? Maybe it should be. But you know how it works. The company doctor reports to the company. The safety inspector is married to the HR director. Nobody wants to be the one who speaks up.
pressure.expression_hint: Looking around the market square nervously

q2_options.text: So the system is rigged to protect the company. Who benefits?
Is there anyone inside the plant willing to confirm this?
What would it take to prove the company doctor is falsifying records?

outcomes.response: Everyone benefits from silence. The company keeps costs down. The union doesn't have to fight. The town keeps its largest employer happy. Only the workers lose.
outcomes.feedback: Structural analysis but no individual evidence. Good context, weak story.
outcomes.note: Systemic silence — company, union, and town all complicit

outcomes.response: There's a nurse at the company clinic — she's been keeping her own notes. Separate from Dr. Holm's official records. She told me she's documented cases where Holm changed diagnoses after meeting with management. She won't go on record but she'd let you see the notes.
outcomes.feedback: Insider witness with separate documentation. Could be verified.
outcomes.note: Clinic nurse keeps parallel records — Holm changes diagnoses after management meetings

outcomes.response: I already have proof. My husband secretly copied his own health file from the clinic when the nurse stepped out. The original says 'suspected occupational hearing damage — recommend specialist.' Dr. Holm's filed version says 'hearing within normal parameters.' Two different documents, same date, same patient. That's not a mistake. That's fraud.
outcomes.feedback: Original vs filed medical record — identical date, contradictory findings. Fraud proof.
outcomes.note: Two versions of same health file: original says 'occupational damage,' filed version says 'normal'

pressure.q1_note: Company doctor reports to company, safety inspector married to HR director

silence.q1_response: ...My husband doesn't know I'm here. He'd be furious. They all would. The men don't want to be seen as weak. They just... keep going. And getting sicker.
silence.expression_hint: Voice dropping almost to a whisper

q2_options.text: Why are the men afraid to speak up themselves?
What does a typical day look like for your husband now?
What made you decide to come forward despite the risk?

outcomes.response: Because the last man who complained about working conditions was transferred to the night shift in the worst department. Everyone knows what happened to Rolf Jansson.
outcomes.feedback: Culture of retaliation established but still secondhand knowledge.
outcomes.note: Rolf Jansson transferred to night shift after complaint

outcomes.response: He comes home grey. Not tired — grey. He sits in the kitchen and doesn't talk because he can barely hear. Last week he couldn't grip a cup — his hand was shaking. He's 38 years old. He used to carry me over the threshold. Now he can't hold a cup.
outcomes.feedback: Devastating human detail. The personal cost made concrete and publishable.
outcomes.note: 38-year-old can't grip a cup — tremors, hearing loss, grey complexion

outcomes.response: Because Erik Forsberg died in May. Same section, same symptoms, same doctor saying 'fine.' The death certificate says 'natural causes.' But nothing about a 45-year-old dying of lung failure is natural when he worked in metal dust for twenty years. I spoke to his widow. She has his personal health diary. He wrote: 'Dr. Holm told me to stop worrying. The dust is harmless.' Three months before he died.
outcomes.feedback: A death, a diary, a doctor's assurance. The cover-up has already cost a life.
outcomes.note: Erik Forsberg dead at 45 — diary quotes Dr. Holm: 'dust is harmless'

silence.q1_note: Husband doesn't know she's speaking to press

headlines.text: Steel Workers Report Health Concerns at Annual Checkup
Independent Doctors Contradict Company Health Records
SICK AND SILENCED — Steel Mill Workers Denied Medical Truth

title: The Housing Fire
description: A fire in worker housing killed two people. The fire department's report raises questions about building safety codes.
lead_text: The fire exit was bolted shut. From the outside. Those people never had a chance.
preview: A document stamped 'CONFIDENTIAL' with the county fire inspector's seal arrives via courier.

interview.opening_line: I sent that report to my superiors four months ago. About the blocked exits, the missing smoke alarms, the overcrowding. They told me to revise it. 'Tone it down.' I revised nothing. So they shelved it.

q1_options.text: That must have been a difficult position, Torsten. What made you decide to send it to us?
I need to see the original report. What specific violations did you document?
Two people are dead. Your report could have prevented it. Why didn't you go public sooner?

friendly.q1_response: Because Margareta Nilsson and her four-year-old are dead. And my report is sitting in a drawer because it would have embarrassed the housing company. Which is owned by the municipality. Which employs me.
friendly.expression_hint: Wiping forehead, looking at the floor

q2_options.text: Who specifically told you to revise the report?
How bad were the conditions in the building?
Are there other buildings with the same problems?

outcomes.response: My supervisor, Kjell Åkesson. He said the timing was 'politically difficult' because the housing company was up for a municipal review. Politics over lives.
outcomes.feedback: Named superior who ordered suppression, but still one person's word.
outcomes.note: Supervisor Kjell Åkesson: 'politically difficult' timing

outcomes.response: The building had fire exits bolted from outside — supposedly to prevent break-ins. No smoke alarms on three floors. Overcrowded — eleven people in four apartments designed for six. The wiring was from the 1940s. I documented everything with photographs.
outcomes.feedback: Comprehensive list of violations with photographic evidence.
outcomes.note: Exits bolted, no alarms, overcrowded, 1940s wiring — all photographed

outcomes.response: I inspected fourteen buildings in the Bruksbo area. Same owner — Industristadens Bostäder AB. Eleven of them have critical fire safety violations. The one that burned was number 7 on my list. There are six buildings ranked worse than it. Here's the full report — the one they didn't want you to see.
outcomes.feedback: Eleven buildings with critical violations. The next fire is a matter of time.
outcomes.note: 11 of 14 buildings have critical violations — original report provided

friendly.q1_note: Margareta Nilsson and 4-year-old dead — report shelved

direct.q1_response: Here. Twenty-three pages. The building at Bruksvägen 14 had seven critical violations. Class A fire risk. I recommended immediate evacuation of the top two floors. They said 'noted' and did nothing.
direct.expression_hint: Opening a battered briefcase, pulling out a thick report

q2_options.text: Who signed off on ignoring your recommendation?
What exactly were the seven critical violations?
When was the last time this building passed an inspection?

outcomes.response: The housing company's board acknowledged receipt. Minutes say 'fire safety improvements to be scheduled pending budget review.' That was March. The fire was in November. Eight months of nothing.
outcomes.feedback: Paper trail of delay but no smoking gun on individual responsibility.
outcomes.note: Board acknowledged in March — no action for 8 months

outcomes.response: Seven violations: locked emergency exits, no smoke detectors on 3 of 4 floors, exposed wiring, blocked stairwell with storage, non-fire-rated doors, no fire extinguishers, and occupancy at 180% of design capacity. Any one of these is enough to close a building.
outcomes.feedback: Seven specific, damning violations. Each individually newsworthy.
outcomes.note: 7 critical violations — any single one grounds for closure

outcomes.response: It 'passed' in 1971. But I pulled the file — the inspector who passed it was Henrik Melin. He now works for Industristadens Bostäder as their 'safety consultant.' Hired three months after the inspection. You understand what I'm saying.
outcomes.feedback: The inspector who approved the building now works for the building owner. Corruption.
outcomes.note: 1971 inspector Henrik Melin now employed by the housing company he cleared

direct.q1_note: 23-page report, 7 critical violations, evacuation recommended

pressure.q1_response: You think I don't know that? You think I sleep at night? I followed procedure. I filed the report. The system failed, not me. But two people are dead and I have to live with that.
pressure.expression_hint: Voice cracking, gripping the table edge

q2_options.text: But did you do everything in your power? Could you have gone higher?
Who else knew about the fire risks besides you and your supervisor?
What's stopping the same thing from happening in the other buildings tomorrow?

outcomes.response: I could have gone to the county governor. I didn't. I followed the chain of command. That was my mistake.
outcomes.feedback: Honest admission of failure, but doesn't advance the investigation much.
outcomes.note: Inspector admits he should have escalated to county governor

outcomes.response: The housing company board knew. The municipal building committee knew — I sent a copy there too. The chairman of that committee is also on the housing company board. Same people on both sides of the table.
outcomes.feedback: Overlapping board membership — structural conflict of interest.
outcomes.note: Municipal committee chairman also sits on housing company board

outcomes.response: Nothing. Nothing is stopping it. And here. I brought this. It's the insurance file for Bruksvägen 14. The building was insured for three times its value. The premium was raised in September — two months before the fire. By the owner. You do the math.
outcomes.feedback: Insurance fraud angle — building over-insured and premium raised before fire. Potential arson motive.
outcomes.note: Building insured at 3x value, premium raised 2 months before fire

pressure.q1_note: Inspector followed procedure — system failed

silence.q1_response: ...I've been carrying this report for four months. Four months of knowing those buildings are death traps and being told to shut up about it. Then the fire happened. And I just... I can't anymore.
silence.expression_hint: Breaking down, hands trembling

q2_options.text: I need to understand the timeline. When exactly did things start going wrong?
Who is ultimately responsible for those buildings?
Tell me about Margareta. Tell me about the people who lived there.

outcomes.response: The buildings were workers' housing, built by the steel company in the '40s. Sold to Industristadens Bostäder in 1968. Since then — no renovations, no maintenance, nothing. Just rent increases.
outcomes.feedback: Historical context and neglect pattern, but no individual accountability.
outcomes.note: No renovations since 1968 sale — only rent increases

outcomes.response: Industristadens Bostäder AB. The board: Karl-Axel Bergström, chairman. The same Bergström who runs the steel mill. Margareta Nilsson worked in his canteen. She lived in his building. She died because he wouldn't spend money on fire exits for his own employee.
outcomes.feedback: Bergström connection — mill director also housing company chairman. Worker died in his building.
outcomes.note: Bergström chairs both steel mill and housing company — victim was his employee

outcomes.response: Margareta was 29. Her daughter Elsa was four. They were on the third floor. The fire door was bolted from outside — a padlock, put there by the caretaker on orders from the housing company to 'prevent unauthorized access.' I photographed it. There's a memo from the housing company manager ordering the locks installed. Here, dated August. Three months before Margareta and Elsa burned.
outcomes.feedback: The memo that killed them. A direct order to lock the fire exits. With names and dates. Devastating.
outcomes.note: Memo ordering fire exits padlocked — dated August, 3 months before deaths

silence.q1_note: Four months of carrying a shelved fire safety report

headlines.text: Fire Department Reviews Building Safety After Deadly Fire
Shelved Report Warned of Fire Risks at Bruksvägen 14
THEY KNEW — Locked Exits, Shelved Reports, Two Dead

title: The School Lunch Scandal
description: The school lunch program is serving food unfit for children while the budget mysteriously shrank.
lead_text: My daughter found mold in her meatball. This was the third time this month.
preview: A parent stops you outside Bruksskolan with a Tupperware container of evidence.

interview.opening_line: I've been raising this at every school board meeting since September. They smile, they nod, and nothing changes. Our children are eating garbage.

q1_options.text: It's clear you care deeply about this, Anna-Lena. How long has the quality been declining?
What's the school lunch budget now versus last year? Where did the money go?
If children are being served expired food, that's a health code violation. Have you reported it?

friendly.q1_response: Since they changed suppliers in August. The old company — Lindströms Catering — was local. Good food. Then suddenly a new company nobody had heard of. 'Norrland Mat AB.' Cheaper, they said. Better value.
friendly.expression_hint: Opening the Tupperware to show grayish meatballs

q2_options.text: Who made the decision to switch suppliers?
What are the specific complaints about the food?
Has anybody looked into this Norrland Mat AB?

outcomes.response: The school board approved it on the municipal education director's recommendation. It was presented as a cost-saving measure. The kids call the new food 'punishment porridge.'
outcomes.feedback: Standard complaint with a good quote but no financial details.
outcomes.note: New supplier recommended by municipal education director

outcomes.response: I've been keeping samples in my freezer. Mold, gristle, once a piece of plastic in the soup. And the portions are smaller — the children are hungry by 2 PM. The teachers have started bringing extra bread because the kids can't concentrate.
outcomes.feedback: Physical evidence preserved, documented pattern, school impact.
outcomes.note: Frozen food samples, smaller portions, teachers bring extra bread

outcomes.response: I looked into Norrland Mat AB. It was registered in June — two months before getting the contract. One employee. The registered address is a post box in Sundsvall. And the owner? Göran Månsson. The education director's brother-in-law. They created a company to funnel school lunch money to family.
outcomes.feedback: Shell company owned by education director's relative. Fraud scheme exposed.
outcomes.note: Norrland Mat AB: shell company, one employee, owned by director's brother-in-law

friendly.q1_note: Supplier changed in August — Norrland Mat AB replaced local company

direct.q1_response: Last year: 12 kronor per meal. This year: 8 kronor. The board approved the reduction because the new supplier 'offered better rates.' But 8 kronor doesn't buy a real meal. Where's the other 4 kronor going? That's 500 children times 4 kronor times 180 school days. You do the math.
direct.expression_hint: Pulling out a calculator, punching numbers

q2_options.text: That's 360,000 kronor. Where is that money now?
Did the board question the budget reduction?
What happens to schoolchildren who don't eat enough?

outcomes.response: The budget line just says 'transferred to school development fund.' I asked what that fund pays for. Nobody could tell me. There's no report, no accounting. 360,000 kronor into a black hole.
outcomes.feedback: Missing money identified but no trail to follow yet.
outcomes.note: 360,000kr transferred to unaccounted 'school development fund'

outcomes.response: I was the only one who voted against it. The education director said the savings would fund new textbooks. I asked to see the textbook purchase order. There isn't one. The money simply disappeared from the school budget into the general municipal account.
outcomes.feedback: Money trail dead end — moved to general account with no spending record.
outcomes.note: Textbook promise was fiction — money moved to general municipal account

outcomes.response: I hired an accountant friend to trace it. The 'school development fund' paid three invoices to Norrland Mat AB for 'consulting services.' On top of the catering contract. 120,000 kronor for consulting from a company with one employee and no office. The education director approved all three invoices. It's embezzlement.
outcomes.feedback: Double billing: catering contract plus fake consulting invoices. Complete fraud trail.
outcomes.note: 3 fake consulting invoices totaling 120,000kr from same shell company — embezzlement

direct.q1_note: Budget cut from 12kr to 8kr per meal — 360,000kr missing

pressure.q1_response: Reported it? To whom? The school board is controlled by the same party that appointed the education director. The health inspector says he needs 'formal complaints in writing.' I've sent four. Ask him how many he's followed up on.
pressure.expression_hint: Slamming a folder of unanswered letters on the desk

q2_options.text: So the oversight system itself has failed?
What exactly did the health inspector say?
Is anyone on the board willing to challenge the director?

outcomes.response: Failed? It was designed to fail. The health inspector gets his budget approved by the same committee the education director sits on. Nobody bites the hand that funds them.
outcomes.feedback: Structural analysis of conflicts of interest. Good context.
outcomes.note: Health inspector budget controlled by same committee as education director

outcomes.response: The health inspector told me off the record — and I have him on tape saying this — 'Anna-Lena, I know the food is bad. But if I write up the school, they'll cut my department.' He's scared for his own job. The system is designed so nobody can afford to do the right thing.
outcomes.feedback: Recorded admission from health inspector. Systemic failure documented.
outcomes.note: Health inspector on tape: 'I know the food is bad' but fears budget cuts

outcomes.response: Last week's board meeting: I presented a motion to return to the previous supplier. The education director called a recess, spoke to three board members privately, and they voted my motion down 5 to 1. After the meeting, one of them whispered to me: 'Sorry, Anna-Lena. Månsson told us the director has photos from the Christmas party. It's blackmail.' They're being coerced.
outcomes.feedback: Blackmail to maintain the fraud scheme. Board members coerced into compliance.
outcomes.note: Board members blackmailed with Christmas party photos — coerced into voting down reform

pressure.q1_note: Four formal complaints to health inspector — zero followed up

silence.q1_response: ...I'll tell you why this matters. It's not just meatballs. It's about who this town serves. The mill director's children go to private school. The workers' children get mold. That's Industristad in one sentence.
silence.expression_hint: Voice quiet but fierce

q2_options.text: Tell me more about the families affected.
Has the quality affected the children's health?
What would you want to see happen?

outcomes.response: Three hundred worker families rely on school lunch as their children's main meal. Many of them can't afford to send packed lunches. When the school serves slop, those kids go hungry. It's a class issue.
outcomes.feedback: Social context established — important for framing but needs specific evidence.
outcomes.note: School lunch is main meal for 300 worker families

outcomes.response: The school nurse reported a 40% increase in stomach complaints since September. She documented it. Twelve children absent in one week in October — all with food poisoning symptoms. She reported it to the education director. He told her to 'stop keeping unofficial statistics.'
outcomes.feedback: Health data from school nurse, suppressed by same director running the scheme.
outcomes.note: 40% increase in stomach complaints — school nurse told to stop tracking

outcomes.response: I want people to know that Norrland Mat AB was previously called Norr Catering. It was shut down by the food safety board in Sundsvall last year for serving contaminated meat to a retirement home. Six elderly people hospitalized. They just changed the name and moved here. The education director knew — he approved a supplier that was already banned. I have the Sundsvall inspection report.
outcomes.feedback: The supplier was previously shut down for food contamination. Renamed and rehired. Criminal negligence.
outcomes.note: Supplier previously shut down in Sundsvall for contaminated meat — renamed and rehired

silence.q1_note: Mill director's kids in private school — workers' kids get mold

headlines.text: Parents Express Concern Over School Lunch Quality
School Lunch Supplier Connected to Education Director's Family
FEEDING ON OUR CHILDREN — How a Shell Company Stole School Lunch Money

title: The Insurance Scam
description: A pattern of denied worker injury claims at the steel mill, despite clear medical evidence.
lead_text: Three workers with the same lung condition. Three denied claims. Same insurance doctor.
preview: A retired mill nurse hands you a folder outside the pharmacy.

interview.opening_line: I kept copies. I knew someday someone would ask. The insurance doctor — Dr. Wennerholm — he never examined them properly. Just ticked 'denied' and moved on.

q1_options.text: You kept records all these years, Sigrid? That took real courage.
How many claims were denied? What's the pattern you found?
Did the company pay Dr. Wennerholm to deny claims? That's fraud.

friendly.q1_response: I was the one who saw them coughing. Who filled out the initial forms. Then the forms came back stamped 'insufficient evidence.' The same men I'd watched deteriorate over years.
friendly.expression_hint: Hands trembling, but voice steady
friendly.q1_note: She filled out forms that came back 'insufficient evidence'

q2_options.text: How many workers were affected? Can you name some of them?
Did you ever confront anyone at the mill about this?
What exactly is in the folder you kept?

outcomes.response: At least a dozen over the years. Gösta Fredriksson, Rune Hellström, others. All the same symptoms. All denied. I mentioned it to the head nurse once. She told me to mind my station.
outcomes.feedback: Names and pattern, but no proof of deliberate fraud. Could be bureaucratic indifference.
outcomes.note: At least a dozen denied, same symptoms

outcomes.response: Fourteen workers between 1968 and 1973. I have their names, dates, symptoms. Every one examined by Dr. Wennerholm. Every one denied. The company doctor before him approved similar claims without issue.
outcomes.feedback: Clear statistical pattern with dates. The switch in approval rates when the doctor changed is damning.
outcomes.note: 14 workers denied by same doctor, previous doctor approved similar cases

outcomes.response: Here. Fourteen files. Each one shows the worker's symptoms, my notes, and Wennerholm's denial. But look at this — I found his contract. He's not independent. Ståhlbergs Stålverk pays him a retainer of 2,000 kronor per month. He's their employee evaluating their liability. It's rigged.
outcomes.feedback: The contract proves the insurance doctor was on the company payroll — a direct conflict of interest. Every denial is now suspect.
outcomes.note: Dr. Wennerholm paid 2,000 kr/month retainer by the mill

direct.q1_response: Fourteen denied claims between 1968 and 1973. All lung-related. All examined by the same insurance doctor — Dr. Wennerholm. The approval rate for similar claims before he started was over 80%. Under him, it dropped to zero.
direct.expression_hint: Opens the folder, points at columns of numbers
direct.q1_note: Approval rate dropped from 80% to 0% under new doctor

q2_options.text: Who hired Dr. Wennerholm? Was it the insurance company or the mill?
What happened to the workers whose claims were denied?
Do you have documentation I can verify independently?

outcomes.response: The insurance company appointed him, officially. But I heard — just heard, mind you — that Bergström's office recommended him. I can't prove that part.
outcomes.feedback: Statistical pattern is strong, but the connection to mill management is hearsay.
outcomes.note: Bergström may have recommended the doctor — unconfirmed

outcomes.response: Three are dead. Gösta Fredriksson can barely breathe. Without the insurance payout, they couldn't afford proper treatment. One man — Arne Lundqvist — sold his house to pay for care. Died six months later.
outcomes.feedback: The human cost is devastating — deaths tied to denied claims. Strong emotional and factual weight.
outcomes.note: Three dead, one sold house for medical care

outcomes.response: Every file, every date, every denial letter. And this — a letter from Bergström to the insurance company: 'We appreciate Wennerholm's thorough approach to claim evaluation.' Dated two weeks after Wennerholm denied four claims in one batch. They were congratulating him for saving them money.
outcomes.feedback: Bergström's letter praising the denials is a smoking gun. The mill actively celebrated workers being denied compensation.
outcomes.note: Bergström congratulated insurance company after batch denials

pressure.q1_response: I... I wouldn't say fraud exactly. But it's not right. The doctor barely looked at them. Five minutes per examination. You can't diagnose industrial lung disease in five minutes.
pressure.q1_note: Five-minute examinations for complex conditions

q2_options.text: If it's not fraud, what would you call systematically denying valid claims?
The workers who were denied — some of them are very sick. Don't they deserve the truth?
Show me the files. Let the evidence speak for itself.

outcomes.response: I'd call it... convenient negligence. The mill saves money. The doctor keeps his contract. The workers suffer in silence. It's how things work here.
outcomes.feedback: She's being careful. 'Convenient negligence' is her framing — accurate but not explosive.
outcomes.note: 'Convenient negligence' — mill saves money, workers suffer

outcomes.response: You're right. They do deserve the truth. Here — look at Rune Hellström's file. Twenty-two years in the smelting hall. Coughing blood. Wennerholm wrote 'chronic bronchitis, non-occupational.' Non-occupational! After twenty-two years breathing steel dust!
outcomes.feedback: The Hellström case is a perfect example — 22 years of exposure dismissed as non-occupational. Absurd on its face.
outcomes.note: 22-year worker's lung disease called 'non-occupational'

outcomes.response: Fine. Here. All fourteen files. And there's something else — I found a memo. Internal. Bergström calculated that denying these claims saved the company 340,000 kronor. He put a number on their suffering. Three hundred and forty thousand.
outcomes.feedback: The internal memo calculating savings from denied claims is the smoking gun. Bergström put a price on workers' health.
outcomes.note: Internal memo: denials saved company 340,000 kronor

silence.q1_response: ...You're not going to push? Good. I've been pushed enough. I kept these files because... because someone should know. Fourteen men. Good men. Thrown away like broken tools.
silence.expression_hint: Opens folder slowly, as if releasing something heavy
silence.q1_note: Fourteen men 'thrown away like broken tools'

q2_options.text: Take your time. I'm listening.
What do you want people to know, Sigrid?

outcomes.response: I want them to know it wasn't an accident. It wasn't bad luck. Someone decided these men weren't worth the paperwork. That's all. Someone decided.
outcomes.feedback: Powerful sentiment but no specifics. 'Someone decided' — but who?
outcomes.note: 'Someone decided these men weren't worth the paperwork'

outcomes.response: Gösta used to sing in the factory choir. Beautiful baritone. Now he can't finish a sentence without coughing. And the insurance company says it's not work-related. After thirty years in the smelting hall. It's obscene.
outcomes.feedback: The Gösta detail is heartbreaking — a singer who can't speak. Thirty years dismissed as coincidence.
outcomes.note: Choir singer who can no longer finish a sentence

outcomes.response: I want them to know about this. *slides a carbon copy across* It's from Bergström to the board. 'Worker compensation liability successfully reduced by 340,000 kronor through revised medical evaluation procedures.' Revised. That's what they call it. Revised.
outcomes.feedback: The carbon copy from Bergström to the board proves this was deliberate policy, not individual negligence. Corporate decision to deny claims.
outcomes.note: Board memo: 'compensation liability reduced by 340,000 kr'

headlines.text: MILL NURSE QUESTIONS INJURY CLAIM PROCESS
14 WORKERS DENIED — SAME DOCTOR, SAME RESULT
STEEL MILL SAVED 340,000 BY DENYING SICK WORKERS

title: The Director's Villa
description: Ståhlbergs Stålverk built a luxury villa for the mill director using company funds — while cutting worker benefits.
lead_text: A construction foreman says the new villa on Bergshöjden was billed to a 'facility maintenance' account at the mill.
preview: An anonymous envelope arrives with a construction invoice marked 'Confidential.'

interview.opening_line: I built that house. Marble floors, imported tiles, a wine cellar. And every invoice went to 'Facility Maintenance — Ståhlbergs Stålverk.' I've got duplicates.

q1_options.text: That's a big thing to share, Birger. What made you come forward?
What's the total cost? And what exactly was billed to the company?
If you built it, you're part of it. Why should anyone trust you now?

friendly.q1_response: My men built worker housing too. Those apartments? Thin walls, no insulation, shared toilets. Meanwhile Bergström gets Italian marble. Same company. Same budget line. Different world.
friendly.expression_hint: Stubs out cigarette, finally turns around
friendly.q1_note: Worker housing vs. director's villa — same budget line

q2_options.text: How much did the villa cost compared to the worker housing?
Who authorized billing it to facility maintenance?
Do you have the invoices with you?

outcomes.response: The villa? At least 400,000 kronor. A worker apartment renovation? 8,000. It's right there in the numbers. But try proving the villa isn't a 'company facility.' That's what they'll say.
outcomes.feedback: The cost disparity is clear, but 'company facility' is a plausible defense. Needs more.
outcomes.note: Villa: 400,000 kr. Worker apartment: 8,000 kr.

outcomes.response: Bergström's personal secretary signed off on every invoice. Eva Sandberg. She coded them to 'Facility Maintenance — General.' The bookkeeper wouldn't know a villa from a warehouse. It's buried in a budget of millions.
outcomes.feedback: The billing chain is clear — Bergström's own secretary approved the fraudulent coding. Traceable.
outcomes.note: Secretary Eva Sandberg signed off, coded as 'General' maintenance

outcomes.response: Here. *slides envelope* Twenty-three invoices. Italian marble — 48,000 kronor. Custom kitchen from Stockholm — 62,000. Wine cellar refrigeration — 15,000. All stamped 'Ståhlbergs Stålverk — Facility Maintenance.' The workers' canteen budget was cut by 50,000 the same quarter.
outcomes.feedback: Twenty-three invoices with specific luxury items, all coded to the mill. The canteen cut in the same quarter is devastating context.
outcomes.note: 23 invoices: marble 48k, kitchen 62k, wine cellar 15k

direct.q1_response: Total? North of 400,000 kronor. Italian marble floors — 48,000. Custom cabinetry — 35,000. The wine cellar alone was 15,000 for the refrigeration unit. All billed as 'facility maintenance' at the mill.
direct.expression_hint: Pulls out a bundle of carbon copies
direct.q1_note: 400,000+ kronor total, all billed to mill maintenance

q2_options.text: Who authorized these invoices? Is there a paper trail?
Does Bergström actually live there? Is it registered as his?
Were any of your workers uncomfortable with this arrangement?

outcomes.response: Bergström's office authorized everything. His secretary handles the paperwork. The invoices come to me, I send them up, they come back approved. I just build what I'm told.
outcomes.feedback: Confirms the authorization chain but positions himself as just following orders. No documentary proof offered.
outcomes.note: Bergström's office approved all invoices

outcomes.response: The property is registered to 'Ståhlbergs Fastigheter AB' — a subsidiary. Bergström is listed as... wait for it... 'tenant.' Rent? One krona per year. One krona. For a 400,000 kronor villa.
outcomes.feedback: The subsidiary ownership and symbolic rent is a classic corporate perk disguised as legitimate. One krona rent is indefensible.
outcomes.note: Bergström 'rents' the 400k villa for 1 krona/year

outcomes.response: Here's what'll really burn them. I have the board meeting minutes where they approved cutting the canteen budget by 50,000 kronor. Same meeting — page four — 'Director housing allocation: 420,000 kronor.' Same meeting. Same page. Workers eat slop so the director gets marble.
outcomes.feedback: Board minutes showing canteen cuts and villa spending approved in the same meeting. The juxtaposition is explosive.
outcomes.note: Same board meeting: cut canteen 50k, allocated villa 420k

pressure.q1_response: Part of it? I'm a contractor. I build what they pay me to build. You want to blame the bricklayer for what the architect designs? Fine. But I'm here now, aren't I?
pressure.expression_hint: Jaw tightens, turns to face you fully
pressure.q1_note: Defensive — 'I build what they pay me to build'

q2_options.text: Fair enough. So what exactly did you build? Walk me through it.
Did you ever question why a private villa was on a company account?
What's in it for you? Why come forward now?

outcomes.response: I questioned it once. Eva Sandberg told me to submit my invoices and keep my mouth shut. So I did. For three years. But now they owe me 32,000 kronor in unpaid bills. So here I am.
outcomes.feedback: He's a disgruntled creditor, not a whistleblower. The unpaid bills motive weakens his credibility, but confirms the billing scheme.
outcomes.note: Wik is owed 32,000 kr — motive for coming forward

outcomes.response: Four bedrooms. Three bathrooms. A sauna. Italian marble in the entrance hall. Custom wine cellar. Heated garage for two cars. This isn't a company guest house — it's a palace. And every kronor came from the same pot that pays for worker safety equipment.
outcomes.feedback: The detailed specifications make it inarguable — this is a private luxury home. The safety equipment budget connection raises the stakes.
outcomes.note: 4 bedrooms, sauna, wine cellar, heated garage — from safety budget

outcomes.response: You want the truth? They didn't just build a house. They made my crew sign non-disclosure agreements. For a 'maintenance project.' When do maintenance workers sign NDAs? When someone has something to hide. I've got my copy right here.
outcomes.feedback: NDAs for construction workers on a 'maintenance project' proves the company knew this was fraudulent. The signed NDA is a document you can photograph.
outcomes.note: Workers forced to sign NDAs for 'maintenance project'

silence.q1_response: ...You're quiet. Good. I don't trust reporters who talk too much. Last guy from Fabriksbladet asked two questions and left. Printed that the villa was a 'company investment in local property.' Useless.
silence.expression_hint: Studies you, then reaches into his jacket pocket
silence.q1_note: Fabriksbladet whitewashed the story

q2_options.text: I'm not from Fabriksbladet.
What didn't the other reporter bother to ask?

outcomes.response: He didn't ask about the wine cellar. Or the marble. Or why a 'company facility' has a private sauna and a heated two-car garage. He saw the nice facade and wrote a nice story. That's this town.
outcomes.feedback: Luxury details are clear but secondhand — your word against theirs without documents.
outcomes.note: Wine cellar, marble, sauna, heated garage

outcomes.response: He didn't ask why Bergström pays one krona per year in rent. One. For a property worth half a million. You could print that single fact and let people do the math.
outcomes.feedback: The one-krona rent is a perfect single-fact story. Simple, devastating, impossible to spin.
outcomes.note: 1 krona/year rent for a 500,000 kr property

outcomes.response: He didn't ask for these. *pulls out folded papers* Board minutes. The canteen budget was cut 50,000 kronor and the 'director housing allocation' of 420,000 was approved in the same meeting. Same page. And here — my crew's NDAs. They made bricklayers sign confidentiality agreements. For 'maintenance.'
outcomes.feedback: Board minutes plus NDAs — the company both approved the spending and tried to hide it. Two documents that tell the whole story.
outcomes.note: Board minutes + crew NDAs: approved spending and hid it

headlines.text: DIRECTOR'S NEW HOME BILLED AS MILL MAINTENANCE
MARBLE FLOORS FOR THE BOSS, THIN SOUP FOR THE WORKERS
420,000 KRONOR VILLA — CANTEEN CUT SAME MEETING

title: The Silent Deaths
description: Workers at the chemical plant have been dying at unusually high rates, but the company's health records show nothing unusual.
lead_text: Five funerals in two years from the chromium division. All men under fifty-five. The company says it's coincidence.
preview: A widow stands at the factory gate holding a photograph.

interview.opening_line: My husband Erik worked in the chromium division for eighteen years. He died in March. Forty-seven years old. They said it was 'general health decline.' He was strong as an ox before he started there.

q1_options.text: I'm sorry for your loss, Gunhild. Can you tell me about Erik?
Five deaths in two years from one division. What do the death certificates say?
The company is calling these coincidences. Do you believe that?

friendly.q1_response: Erik loved fishing. Weekends at the lake, always. When he started losing weight, he said it was the shift work. Then the coughing started. Then the blood. It took fourteen months from the first symptom to the funeral.
friendly.expression_hint: Holding the photograph against her chest
friendly.q1_note: 14 months from first symptoms to death

q2_options.text: Did Erik ever talk about conditions in the chromium division?
Have you spoken to the other widows? Are their stories similar?
What did the doctors say was the cause?

outcomes.response: He said the ventilation never worked properly. Yellow dust on everything. They gave them paper masks — flimsy things that fell apart in an hour. He'd come home with yellow fingers.
outcomes.feedback: Poor ventilation and inadequate masks suggest exposure, but no direct link to deaths established.
outcomes.note: Yellow dust, paper masks that fell apart in an hour

outcomes.response: Maja Lindqvist lost her husband in September. Britta Holm, hers in January. We talk. All the same — weight loss, coughing, blood. And all the death certificates say different things. 'Respiratory failure.' 'Liver disease.' 'Cardiac arrest.' Never the word 'chromium.' Never 'occupational.'
outcomes.feedback: Three widows, same symptoms, but different causes of death on certificates — a pattern of avoiding the occupational link.
outcomes.note: Three widows, same symptoms, different listed causes of death

outcomes.response: Erik kept a diary. He wrote down every day his eyes burned, every nosebleed, every time the ventilation broke down. And he wrote this, three months before he died: 'Foreman Berg said if we report the ventilation we'll be moved to the loading dock at half pay. So we breathe the dust and shut up.'
outcomes.feedback: The diary is firsthand documentation — a worker recording his own poisoning, plus the foreman's threat against reporting. Devastating.
outcomes.note: Diary: foreman threatened workers who reported ventilation issues

direct.q1_response: I have Erik's death certificate here. 'Respiratory failure due to chronic pulmonary condition.' No mention of chromium. No mention of occupation. I checked with Maja Lindqvist — her husband's says 'liver disease.' Britta Holm's husband: 'cardiac arrest.' Same division, same symptoms, different causes.
direct.expression_hint: Unfolds documents with careful, practiced movements
direct.q1_note: Same symptoms, different causes on death certificates

q2_options.text: Did anyone request an independent autopsy or occupational health review?
Who signed the death certificates? The same doctor?
What do you know about chromium exposure and its health effects?

outcomes.response: I asked for a review. The company doctor — Dr. Wennerholm — said there was 'no evidence of occupational causation.' The union rep said he'd look into it. That was four months ago. Nothing.
outcomes.feedback: Same company doctor blocking investigation as in the insurance story. Pattern of suppression, but no proof.
outcomes.note: Company doctor found 'no evidence of occupational causation'

outcomes.response: Different doctors signed them, but the cause-of-death summaries all came through Dr. Wennerholm's office first. He reviews all worker deaths at the mill. He decides what to write. And he never writes 'occupational.'
outcomes.feedback: Wennerholm acting as gatekeeper for cause-of-death classification. He filters out occupational causes before other doctors sign.
outcomes.note: Wennerholm reviews all worker deaths, never writes 'occupational'

outcomes.response: A doctor in Gothenburg — not connected to the mill — told me hexavalent chromium is a known carcinogen. Banned in many countries. Not here. And I found this in Erik's locker. *hands over a paper* Air quality measurements from 1971. Someone at the mill tested it once. The chromium levels were fourteen times the recommended limit. This paper was never shown to the workers.
outcomes.feedback: Internal air quality test showing 14x the safe limit — the company knew and buried the evidence. Combined with five deaths, this is front-page material.
outcomes.note: Internal test: chromium levels 14x recommended limit, hidden from workers

pressure.q1_response: Coincidence? Five men, same division, same symptoms, all dead before fifty-five? If that's coincidence, then I'm the Queen of Sweden. The company knows. They've always known.
pressure.expression_hint: Voice rising, gripping the photograph tighter
pressure.q1_note: 'Five men, same symptoms, all dead before 55'

q2_options.text: What proof do you have that the company knew about the danger?
Has anyone tried to hold the company accountable? Any legal action?
What happened when you confronted the company directly?

outcomes.response: I went to the personnel office. They gave me a condolence letter and Erik's last paycheck. When I asked about the chromium, the woman behind the desk said she didn't know what I was talking about. 'We don't use chromium here.' They do. Everyone knows they do.
outcomes.feedback: The company denying chromium use when it's common knowledge shows institutional lying, but it's her word against theirs.
outcomes.note: Company denied using chromium — an obvious lie

outcomes.response: A lawyer in Gothenburg agreed to look at it. But he needs proof of exposure. The company controls all the records. Erik's personal doctor documented the symptoms but couldn't prove the cause without the company's workplace data. They won't release it.
outcomes.feedback: Company withholding workplace data from legal proceedings — obstruction that itself is newsworthy.
outcomes.note: Company refusing to release workplace exposure data to lawyers

outcomes.response: I'll tell you what happened. Bergström himself called me. Personally. Offered 15,000 kronor. He called it a 'goodwill payment.' On the condition I sign a paper saying Erik's death was 'not related to his employment.' Fifteen thousand kronor for my husband's life. And my silence.
outcomes.feedback: Bergström personally offering hush money is explosive — it proves the company knows the deaths are work-related. Why pay for silence if there's nothing to hide?
outcomes.note: Bergström offered 15,000 kr 'goodwill' for silence agreement

silence.q1_response: ...Five funerals. I stood at five funerals. All the same church. All the same coughing in the months before. The priest doesn't say anything either. No one in this town says anything.
silence.expression_hint: Long pause, then looks at the photograph
silence.q1_note: 'Five funerals, same church, same coughing'

q2_options.text: I'm here to listen, Gunhild.
Why do you think no one speaks up?

outcomes.response: Because the mill is everything. It's the jobs, the housing, the school, the football team. You don't speak against the mill. You just... bury your husbands and keep quiet.
outcomes.feedback: Captures the company-town dynamic perfectly, but no evidence of wrongdoing. Just the silence itself.
outcomes.note: 'You bury your husbands and keep quiet'

outcomes.response: Erik's foreman — Berg — he came to the funeral. Stood in the back. Didn't sign the guest book. After the service he pulled me aside and said: 'It should have been better. The ventilation. I told them.' Then he left. That was his confession.
outcomes.feedback: The foreman's admission at the funeral — he told management about the ventilation. An inside witness who confirms the company was warned.
outcomes.note: Foreman Berg admitted at funeral: 'I told them' about ventilation

outcomes.response: Because last time someone spoke, they were destroyed. Sven Bergqvist — the train driver — he reported the loading violations. They blacklisted him. But Erik... Erik was smarter. He wrote everything down. *hands over a small notebook* Dates. Symptoms. Names. Air that tasted like metal. He knew he was dying. He documented it for someone like you.
outcomes.feedback: Erik's daily log is a martyred worker's testimony — he documented his own death, knowing someone would eventually read it. Powerful and legally significant.
outcomes.note: Erik kept a daily symptom diary knowing he was dying

headlines.text: WIDOW QUESTIONS HUSBAND'S DEATH AT CHEMICAL PLANT
FIVE DEAD UNDER 55 — SAME DIVISION, SAME SYMPTOMS
COMPANY OFFERED WIDOW 15,000 KR TO STAY SILENT

title: The Double Agent
description: The local union chairman has been secretly negotiating with management — trading wage increases for personal benefits.
lead_text: A disgruntled union member found draft agreements in the chairman's office that were never shown to the membership.
preview: A sealed envelope arrives with photocopied documents and a note: 'Check Folke's deal.'

interview.opening_line: Folke Dahlberg sold us out. I found the papers in his desk when he was in Stockholm. Secret agreements. The membership voted for a 12% raise. Folke settled for 4% — and a company car for himself.

q1_options.text: That must have been devastating to discover. How long has this been going on?
What exactly was in the agreements? What did Dahlberg get personally?
You broke into his desk. That's not exactly clean either, is it?

friendly.q1_response: Two years. Maybe more. We kept losing negotiations and couldn't figure out why. Management always seemed to know our bottom line. Our strike votes, our breaking points. Now I know — Folke told them everything.
friendly.expression_hint: Leg bouncing, chain-smoking intensifies
friendly.q1_note: Two years of leaked negotiation positions

q2_options.text: What proof do you have beyond the documents you found?
Have you confronted Folke about this?
How did the workers react to the 4% settlement?

outcomes.response: The workers were furious. We had leverage — the oil crisis means production can't stop. But Folke settled before we could vote on a strike. Said management threatened layoffs. Now I know why — he had his deal already.
outcomes.feedback: Circumstantial — a bad settlement doesn't prove corruption. You need the documents themselves.
outcomes.note: Folke settled before strike vote, claiming layoff threats

outcomes.response: I confronted him. He turned white. Then he said: 'You don't understand how negotiation works.' But I had the carbon copies. Three side agreements. A company Volvo. Paid 'consulting fees' — 800 kronor a month. And a guaranteed supervisor job for his son.
outcomes.feedback: Three documented side deals — car, consulting fees, nepotism. Folke's reaction when confronted confirms their authenticity.
outcomes.note: Volvo, 800 kr/month 'consulting,' supervisor job for his son

outcomes.response: Here. *slams papers on the table* Three side agreements, all signed by Folke and Bergström's deputy. But this is the one that matters — a letter from Bergström: 'As discussed, the 4% settlement protects both parties. Your continued cooperation is valued.' Bergström is thanking our union chairman for selling his own members short.
outcomes.feedback: Bergström's letter proves the collaboration was explicit and mutual. The mill director thanking the union chairman for betraying workers. Explosive.
outcomes.note: Bergström letter: 'Your continued cooperation is valued'

direct.q1_response: Three side agreements. One: company Volvo 142, registered to Folke's wife. Two: 'consulting fees' of 800 kronor per month to a company Folke's brother runs. Three: his son Lars gets a supervisor position without the normal qualifications.
direct.expression_hint: Spreads photocopies across the table
direct.q1_note: Company car, 800 kr/month consulting, nepotism hire

q2_options.text: Are these originals or copies? Can they be verified?
What did the union membership actually vote for versus what Folke agreed to?
Has Folke done this in previous negotiations too?

outcomes.response: Carbon copies. The originals are in Bergström's office, probably. But these are clearly company letterhead. You can see the watermark. And Folke's signature — I know his handwriting.
outcomes.feedback: Carbon copies are evidence but weaker than originals. Folke could claim forgery.
outcomes.note: Carbon copies on company letterhead with Folke's signature

outcomes.response: We voted to demand 12% with a strike mandate. Folke came back three days later with 4% and no strike. He told us management threatened to close the mill. We believed him. Meanwhile, his wife was driving a new Volvo.
outcomes.feedback: The gap between the mandate (12% + strike) and the result (4%, no strike) is stark. The timeline and the car make the corruption visible.
outcomes.note: Voted 12% + strike mandate; got 4% with no strike

outcomes.response: I went back further. Three previous negotiations — same pattern. Workers demanded, Folke settled for less, and something always appeared. The car was 1973. Before that, his apartment was renovated — 'a company benefit for long-serving employees.' No other employee got that offer. The consulting payments started in 1972. It's systematic.
outcomes.feedback: Three years of escalating personal benefits tied to each under-delivered negotiation. The pattern over time proves this isn't a one-off — it's a business arrangement.
outcomes.note: Three years of side deals tied to each negotiation

pressure.q1_response: I didn't break in. The drawer was unlocked. I was looking for the actuarial tables for the pension discussion. What I found was... different. And yes, I took copies. Someone had to.
pressure.expression_hint: Defensive, but pulls out papers anyway
pressure.q1_note: Found documents while looking for pension data

q2_options.text: What exactly did you find? Show me everything.
Why you? Why not go to the national union instead of a newspaper?
Is Folke popular with the workers? Will they believe this?

outcomes.response: Folke is... respected. Not loved, but respected. Thirty years in the movement. People trust him because they've always trusted him. That's what makes this so ugly.
outcomes.feedback: Context about Folke's reputation, but no new evidence. The betrayal angle is strong emotionally.
outcomes.note: Folke: 30 years in the movement, respected and trusted

outcomes.response: I tried the national union. Called Stockholm. They said they'd 'investigate internally.' That was two months ago. Nothing. Maybe they knew. Maybe the rot goes higher. That's when I called you.
outcomes.feedback: National union inaction suggests either incompetence or complicity. The leak goes to the press as last resort — credible and significant.
outcomes.note: National union promised to investigate — two months, nothing

outcomes.response: Fine — everything. Three side agreements, two personal letters from Bergström, and this: a handwritten note from Folke to Bergström. 'The boys will accept 4%. Hold firm at 3% for two days, then offer 4. They'll feel like they won.' Our chairman scripted the entire negotiation against us.
outcomes.feedback: Folke's own handwritten note coaching management on how to manipulate the union. He scripted the workers' own defeat. This is the most devastating document.
outcomes.note: Folke coached Bergström: 'Hold firm at 3%, offer 4, they'll feel they won'

silence.q1_response: ...Thirty years I've worked alongside Folke. Thirty years. And the whole time... *long pause* ...the whole time he was selling us. Do you know what that feels like? Like finding out your father is a stranger.
silence.expression_hint: Stares at the road, leg stops bouncing
silence.q1_note: 'Like finding out your father is a stranger'

q2_options.text: What made you finally look?
Take your time, Anders.

outcomes.response: Something didn't add up. Every negotiation, Folke knew exactly when to fold. Always had a reason. 'They'll close the mill.' 'The economy's bad.' But it was always just enough to stop us fighting. Always exactly management's number.
